dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An establishing shot of the rundown train station on an  overcast morning. There's snow on the station platform. A train arrives and departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other parts of the world, young  men of promise leave home to make  their fortunes, battle evil, or solve  the problems of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the station, at the top of the hill, lies the St.  Cloud's orphanage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was myself such a young man, when  I came to save the orphanage in St.  Cloud's... many years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man and woman (COUPLE #1) make their way toward the mai entrance of the large brick building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here in St. Cloud's, I have come to  understand that promises are rarely  kept, that the battle isn't so much  against evil as ignorance, and that  being successful can't hold a candle  to being of *use*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The couple enters the orphanage, where we hear the sound babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor have I solved the problem I came  here to solve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two nurses, EDNA and ANGELA, chase CHILDREN--a morning  routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even in the most enlightened times,  unwanted babies will manage to be  born. That there will always be  orphans is simple not a problem to  be solved. Here is St. Cloud's, we  don't regard the sordid facts of  life as problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera goes up the stairs with some of the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We enter an office where DR. LARCH shows couple #1 their  newly adopted son, HOMER, an infant who lies smiling in D Larch's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In truth, we've only had one real  problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We close in on the infant until his face fills the screen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name was Homer Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch hands over the infant to the adopting parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I named him after the Greek writer.  You know Homer, of course?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hesitant nods. (They don't look as if they read.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made his name "Wells" because I  could tell he was very deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parents look with pride at their adopted son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In truth, Nurse Angela named him-- her father *drilled* wells, and  "Homer" was one of her family's  umpteen cats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the front door, Larch and the nurses wave and call goo bye to Homer, they close the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same door swings open; it's another night. The same c is bringing Homer back. There is concern in their faces a Nurse Edna lets them in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch is delivering his benediction to the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Good night, you Princes of Maine,  you Kings of New England!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns, he is startled by Nurse Edna, waiting with c #1 and baby Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something wrong with him! He  never makes a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch looks quickly at Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't cry enough for them, if  you can believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we could have a look at  someone a little different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mother hands over the baby to Larch. Baby Homer lets a happy squeal as soon as he's in Larch's arms. The paren stare in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thus was Homer Wells returned. He  was too happy a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela and Edna call and wave good-bye to a two-year-old  Homer, leaving with COUPLE #2. Larch stands on the porch watches the family head down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second family has an unfortunate  gift for getting sounds out of Homer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COUPLE
dialogues.text: Larch bursts into the home of the second couple and lifts crying and bruised Homer out of his bed. There is rage in Larch's eyes as he looks at the couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rumor was true. They beat him.  He couldn't stop crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch carries Homer up the orphanage hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is St. Cloud's, I try to  consider, with each rule I make or  break, that my first priority is an  orphan's future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The naked belly of a VERY PREGNANT WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easier said than done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny hand comes in with a stethoscope and puts it on th big belly. Young Homer's head, with the stethoscope aroun his neck, pops up behind the belly; he closes his eyes as concentrates on listening to the sounds of the unborn chi Larch stops in the doorway, catching sight of Homer. He s faintly.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUPLE
dialogues.text: The door opens to a THIRD COUPLE smiling at us, welcoming and embracing a sixteen-year-old Homer. Behind them waits the would-be STEPSISTER--an attractive girl, a little old then Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told the third family to take good  care--this was a special boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and the stepsister are in bed together. The parents burst in on them--the father chasing Homer around and aro the bed, the mother beating her daughter, who covers hers with a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Homer who took too much good  care of himself.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUPLE
dialogues.text: From her window, the stepsister watches Homer leave the h carrying his suitcase. Homer looks up at her as he walks the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's after dawn, but still a little dark, as Homer walks the orphanage door, suitcase in hand. A HUGELY PREGNANT W arrives at the same time. They stand awkwardly next to ea other, waiting for someone to answer the door. The woman crying. Homer reaches out and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be frightened. Everyone is  nice here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you live here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just belong here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman sniffles; she nods vaguely. The door opens. Nur Edna lets the woman in and embraces Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could I do with him? He kept  coming back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch instructs an older Homer from "Gray's Anatomy." Hom is bored and looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, if you're going to stay at  St. Cloud's, I expect you to be of  use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks adoringly at Dr. Larch as Larch examines ANOT PREGNANT WOMAN. Larch waves Homer over; he places the boy hand on the woman's abdomen, to feel the fetus kicking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, in failing to withhold love,  had I created a true and everlasting  orphan? I had been too successful  with Homer Wells. I had managed to  make the orphanage his *home*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch closes a door quickly behind him (so that Homer doe see the ABORTION PATIENT in the O.R.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer assists Larch in delivering a BABY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer carries a white enamel pail to the incinerator. He  looks inside the pail; he stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God forgive me. I have *made* an  orphan by loving him too much. Homer  Wells will belong to St. Cloud's,  forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on Homer's disgusted expression as he stares at the  contents of the pail. END TITLE SEQUENCE. FADE OUT. We hear a song playing on a old phonograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the song playing on the old phonograph. Dr. Larch taking ether. He holds the bottle in one hand, the cone o his mouth and nose with the other. SUPER: ST. CLOUD'S, MAINE, MARCH 1943. When Larch dozes off, his hand loosens its grip on the co the cone falls off his face, and he wakes up. Then he put the cone back in place, dripping more ether from the bott to the gauze covering the cone. Pan the dispensary, which also serves as Larch's photo ga and bedroom apartment. The ether-bed is separated from th room by a hospital curtain (the kind on casters). We see recording revolving, the glass-encased cabinets of medica supplies, the old photographs of St. Cloud's. Homer enters, he stands uncomfortably, watching Larch for moment. Then he turns around and walks back into the corr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer calls out as though he's just coming down the corri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch! Dr. Larch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch wakes up; he shakes off the ether haze. Homer reent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got two new patients, one to  deliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch and Homer leave together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The *two* doctors walk briskly down the hall, a couple of professionals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First pregnancy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, for both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) I presume you'd prefer handling the  delivery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tiredly; an old topic) All I said was, I don't want to  perform abortions. I have no argument  with *you* performing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know *how* to help these women-- how can you not feel *obligated* to  help them when they can't get help  anywhere else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One: it's illegal. Two: I didn't ask  how to do it--you just showed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What *else* could I have showed you,  Homer? The only thing I can teach  you is what I know! In every life,  you've got to be of use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Larch split off and disappear into two differen operating rooms. As he goes, Homer mumbles to himself, "O use, of use, of use."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch and Angela are preparing the ether for DOROTHY, a n visibly pregnant woman. The sounds of labor across the ha can be heard Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds the cone) Have you ever had ether, Dorothy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once, when they took out my appendix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks for scar) No one's touched your appendix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it was... the ether made me  sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't make you sick this time,  Dorothy--not the way I do it, just a  drop at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't pay for this, you know--I  got no money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day, Dorothy, if you have any  money, a donation to the orphanage  would be very much appreciated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you can afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds the ether bottle) Try to think of nothing, Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela puts the cone over Dorothy's mouth and nose; Larch drips the ether on the cone. A newborn wails in the other O.R. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer has delivered CARLA. A newborn baby is screaming in Edna's arms. Homer is attending to Carla, who is panting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was good, Carla--that was  *perfect*. Everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna see it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to see it, dear. Don't  worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even wanna know what sex it  is--don't tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't tell you, Carla. You're  going to be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your *baby's* going to be okay, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch pops into the delivery room; he peers at the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a big boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see him, for Christ's sake--I  wanna see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna shows the baby to Carla, who stares, then turns away Larch whispers to Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind having a look at  Dorothy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela sits with the still-etherized Dorothy while Larch Homer confer over a basin containing Dorothy's uterus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no visible wound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The fetus was dead. Her uterus  was virtually *disintegrating*--my  stitches pulled right through the  tissue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mystified) It looks like scurvy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (derisively sarcastic) Scurvy! Ah yes, the curse of the old- time sailor, suffering long periods  at sea with no fresh fruits or  vegetables. Homer, Dorothy isn't a  *sailor*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a prostitute, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Angela) Did you look in her purse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) I looked everywhere else!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela hands Larch a bottle of brown liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called French Lunar Solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch wrinkles his nose at the odor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not ergot, it's not pituitary  extract, it's not oil of rue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It claims to restore monthly  regularity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's obviously an aborticide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch wets his finger with the stuff, then touches it to tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spits) Christ, it's oil of tansy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you take enough of it, your  intestines lose their ability to  absorb Vitamin C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words, scurvy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good boy. Good job. And you call  yourself "not a doctor"! (to Angela) Keep an eye on her--she's in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Homer turns to leave, Larch stops him; he points to th basin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of that, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer stops, annoyed; he picks up the basin and empties t contents into a white enamel pail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS TITCOMB is teaching math to some distracted boys and girls in a corner of the dining room. A blackboard on whe is a mass of numbers. Homer, passing through the dining r with the white enamel pail, attracts the attention of BUS a sixteen-year-old who is picking over a plate of pastrie on a table. Buster immediately goes with Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer shakes his head, keeps walking. Buster follows. Dr. Larch passes close to Buster. Buster makes a face, disgus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster and Homer tramp through the snow toward the  incinerator. Homer still carries the pail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He *sniffs* that ether! I've seen  him do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because he's too tired to sleep.  He has to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He *smells* like he could put you to  sleep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a doctor, Buster--doctors smell  like ether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *You're* a doctor, Homer--you don't  smell like ether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm *not* a doctor. I haven't been  to medical school--I haven't even  been to high school!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've studied with the old man  for *years*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm *not* a doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster stands watching as Homer empties the pail into the incinerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his head inclined to the giant ear of Larch's phonog FUZZY--six, thin, and pale and looking remarkably like an embryo--is listening to a recording. He can't hear what L and Homer are saying about him as they construct a humidi tent over a small hospital bed on wheels. The humidifier operated by a car battery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuzzy is not uncommon. I tell you,  there's something about the premature  babies of alcoholic mothers. They  seem susceptible to every damn thing  that comes along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't read that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't, either. But you *will*.  The morons who write the books should  do a little research *here*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But isn't Fuzzy just... well,  underdeveloped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When *doesn't* he have bronchitis? I  wouldn't call his bronchial infections  "underdeveloped." Would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch plucks Fuzzy from in front of the phonograph and zi him into the breathing tent. Fuzzy smiles. As larch leave MARY AGNES, a pretty but tough-looking teenager, comes in the dispensary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Mary Agnes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Agnes smiles at Homer; then she sticks her tongue ou at him. Homer looks at her impassively, but as the moment continues his expression suggests his annoyance. Fuzzy st to cough; he wheezes as he breathes. Homer leans down; he peers at Fuzzy through a hole by the zipper of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (garbled because of  her tongue) Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer examines Mary Agnes' tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bite it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissively) It looks like you bit it--it'll be  all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I was kissing someone and he  bit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her tongue  again) No, you did it yourself. Maybe in  your sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have been *dreaming* of kissing  someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is not responding to her come-on. He wheels Fuzzy i the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Story time, Fuzzy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the girls' bunk room, Nurse Edna is saying prayers. Th girls lie with their palms pressed together on their ches

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh Lord, support us all the day  long..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building of St. Cloud's is silhouetted against the sk Carla, the woman we saw deliver the baby, is heading down the hill alone, she sobs, not looking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...until the shadows lengthen and  the evening comes, and the busy world  is hushed, and the fever of life is  over, and our work is done."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bunk room again, with Edna and the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Then in Thy mercy grant us save  lodging, and holy rest, and peace at  the last."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen! Amen! Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch is reading from Oliver Twist--the death scene o Bill Sike's dog. The boys listen in horror in their beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A dog, which had lain concealed  till now, ran backwards and forwards  on the parapet with a dismal howl,  and collecting himself for a spring,  jumped for the dead man's shoulders."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer enters; he walks quietly to his bed in the far corn of the room, where he starts to undress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Missing his aim, he fell into a  ditch, turning completely over as he  went; and striking his head against  a stone, dashed his brains out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch turns out the lights. From the open doorway to the  hall, Larch delivers his nightly benediction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, you Princes of Maine!  You Kings of New England!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch closes the door, leaving them in the semi-darkness. One young boy runs into Homer's bed, nervously giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in his breathing  tent) Why does Dr. Larch *do* tht every  night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about seven) Maybe to scare us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about eleven) No, you jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about nine) Dr. Larch *loves* us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why does he do *that*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does it because we like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys silently agree, Homer among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls, led by Mary Agnes, round a corner of the orpha towing a sled piled high with snowballs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster is mine. You two get  Copperfield and Curly. Nobody touches  Fuzzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shriek as the boys suddenly surprise them. Buster th two hard snowballs that hit Mary Agnes and CLARA (eight o nine) before Mary Agnes overwhelms him and repeatedly sti his head in the snow. Copperfield, terrified of Mary Agne escapes. Curly misses, then tips over the sled of snowbal as Clara and the adorable HAZEL (five or six) throw him t the ground. Fuzzy drops his one snowball; he runs aimless in circles, coughing, as Nurse Edna explodes from a door the orphanage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! No fighting! *Share* the  snowballs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full of snow) They're *our* snowballs! They *stole*  them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They attacked us--just like the Japs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuzzy coughs and wheezes, trying to catch his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to you, Fuzzy! You've been  running. You get to the shower!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NEW COUPLE comes up the hill. The orphans stop and star brushing snow off themselves, struggling to make themselv look presentable. Curly is desperate to look his best. Ma Agnes doesn't bother to pretty herself. She whispers to C and Hazel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the type--they'll take one of  the babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are eating breakfast as the would-be parents walk around the tables, looking over the assembled orphan Curly works on his table manners; he forks and eats a pie of pancake with elegance. Angela and Edna try to make the couple slow down by the older children, but the couple st and stare at the adorable Hazel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch and Homer are examining the babies. The doctors are checking the babies' grips, their eyes, ears, and throats Angela appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilbur, the adopting couple is waiting  in your office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) Life is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela disappears. Larch looks at the next baby's record  (attached to the bed).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the name sheet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's named this one yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my turn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is tired of this game. Larch touches the child's  forehead with his index finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henceforth you shall be... Little  Dorrit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't like it. (looks at the record) He's a boy, That's why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't a boy be a Dorrit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer points his finger at the child's forehead like a gu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henceforth you shall be... Little  Wilbur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not crazy about the "Little..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is writing the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, he's just a Wilbur then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't had a Wilbur here in a  year or so, have we? We used to have  *dozens*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are interrupted by Copperfield, who comes running fr the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They picked Hazel! The idiots chose  Hazel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazel is being fussed over by Edna. Hazel clutches a card suitcase and a tattered rag doll. Mary Agnes, by far the  oldest, sits on a bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If people want to adopt one of us,  they should have to take the oldest  first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mary Agnes! This is Hazel's  special day--don't make her feel  sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazel's practically the youngest of  us. She should be the *last* to leave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least Hazel can talk. Usually  they take one of the stupid babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take the babies so they won't  ever have to tell them that they  were orphans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (begins to cry) I'm not a baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you cry, Hazel, they'll just send  you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Agnes, that's not true!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazel cries harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they did to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You *wanted* to come back--that's  why you cried. (to Hazel) You can cry if you feel like it,  Hazel. You cry as much as you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is in the corridor outside the office, overhearing  Larch's lecture to the couple adopting Hazel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is strictly for our orphans' sake  that I destroy any record of their  natural mothers. Of course they will,  one day, want to know. But orphans,  especially, should look forward to  their *futures*. Not back to their  pasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer sees Curly standing all alone by a window in the  corridor; a suitcase is next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Curly. You going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they might take me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wanted a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody ever wants me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer embraces Curly and lifts him up, he grabs the suitc and continues down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're one of the best, Curly--we  couldn't let just anyone take you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch wouldn't let just anyone  take *any* of us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's asked for me, have they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody special enough, Curly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean somebody asked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the right people can have you,  Curly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer disappears into the boys' bunk room carrying Curly his suitcase, leaving the corridor empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faces in the windows; the orphans watch Hazel walking acr the snowy lawn with her new parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna (with the girls) gives her good-bye blessing to Haze

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us be happy for Hazel. Hazel has  found a family. Good night, Hazel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Hazel! Good night, Hazel!  Good night, Hazel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens. The orphans excitedly run outside o the green lawn, into the warm weather of spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela is singing along with the song on the phonograph, more romantic song then before, which rouses Larch from h ether. He is grumpy, but she sings the song in his ear an won't give him back the ether cone; he rolls away from he but she tickles him and bites his ear, coaxing him into a more playful mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was dreaming about you. How  beautiful you were!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't dreaming about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playfully, she slips out of his embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I wasn't beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were! You *are*! It was fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just the ether, Wilbur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer wheels a tray with glasses of water between the bed A DISTRAUGHT PREGNANT WOMAN stops him by her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Can I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one but me ever put a hand on me,  to feel that baby. Don't you want to  touch it or put your ear down to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer touches the woman's belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your ear there. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer cautiously lays his ear against her belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have a baby if there's  no one who wants to put his face  right there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds Homer's head against her belly; she presses his face into her. She shuts her eyes. Homer's eyes stare wid Dr. Larch stops in the doorway; he watches with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay right there. Right where you  are. Stay right here. Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer at the train station, staring down the empty tracks Buster is hanging around with him, kicking a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever think about leaving this  place to go find them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer makes no response. As the train approaches, Homer a Buster go sit on a loading cart. They see the distraught  woman (no longer pregnant) from Homer's experience of a f nights ago; she is leaving St. Cloud's without her baby,  waiting for the approaching train. Her face is a mask. Th DISAPPROVING STATIONMASTER gives her a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean your parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who you mean. I think about  leaving here, but not to find *them*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever they were, they didn't *do*  any of the things parents are supposed  to do. Dr. Larch did those things,  and Nurse Edna, and Nurse Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But sometimes I wish I could  meet mine, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for, Buster? What would you do  if you met them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... I'd like to show them that I  can cook, a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cook very well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that I can drive a truck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Better than I can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I want to meet them so I  can kill them. Just sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster is ashamed; he knows he's said the wrong thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, you know I would never kill  anyone--you know I wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slowly moving train has stopped. There are SOLDIERS  leaning out the windows. Buster turns to see Mary Agnes  walking past the train--she's doing her best to look grow up, sophisticated. One of the soldiers reaches out and ge tugs on  her hair. Mary Agnes is enraged; she spits at th soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Mary Agnes could kill someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it. She's just an...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Agnes spits at *all* the soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...emotional girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers roll up the windows as Mary Agnes improvises some verbal abuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she so emotional about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I don't know. She got left here,  like the rest of us, didn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera closes on Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orphans are watching King Kong, the part when the gia ape first captures the screaming Fay Wray. Intercut Kong  with the orphans' rapt faces. Homer sits near the front,  mesmerized by the film. Dr. Larch and Angela sit by the  projector; Larch is reading a letter. Fuzzy points to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughing) He thinks she's his *mother*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King Kong is undressing Fay Wray in the cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't think she's his mother,  Fuzzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does so! He *loves* her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could she be his *mother*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch shakes the letter in front of Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a harsh whisper) They want to replace me! The Board  of Trustees wants to *replace* me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering back) They just want you to hire some new  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some new *things* would be useful. I  don't need any "new help."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film breaks--to huge cries of disappointment from the orphans. Fuzzy coughs and coughs while Larch fumbles with the projector. Angela turns on the light while Larch squi at the broken film. The orphans are chanting, "Kong! Kong

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer! I need you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer gets up and walks to the projector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you took care of this. It  always breaks in the same place.  It's your splice, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) It's *your* splice! You blame me for  everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch abruptly lets go of the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela, we need a new movie, a new  projector, a new typewriter--*that's*  what they should replace around here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna comes in; she speaks to Larch, then quickly leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a delivery. Imminent, in my  estimation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch turns to Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, would you get this one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer shifts his weight to the other foot; aggravated; he stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a patient, right? She should  see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Larch stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to stay calm) Homer, you are a skilled and gifted  surgeon. You have near-prefect  obstetrical and gynecological  procedure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is also trying to avoid a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just mean I'd rather fix the movie.  Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch can't hide his disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Okay. You splice. I'll deliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is an uneasy peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is adjusting Fuzzy's breathing tent as the other bo climb into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer... doesn't King Kong think the  woman is his *mother*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, sure--that's what Kong thinks,  all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why Kong loves her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch comes in and walks over to Homer and Fuzzy. Larch a Homer exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was my turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. I'll get this. You go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer sits down with 'David Copperfield.' There is quiet  anticipation while Homer readies himself to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Whether I shall turn out to be the  hero of my own life, or whether that  station will be held by anybody else,  these pages must show."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch continues to adjust Fuzzy's breathing tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I was a posthumous child. My father's  eyes had closed upon the light of  this world six months, when mine  opened on it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Larch) His father's dead, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering back) That's right, Fuzz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Fuzzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues reading) "There is something strange to me,  even now, in the reflection that he  never saw me..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Larch bends over Fuzzy to fix the breathing apparatus, Fuzzy whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is *your* father dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, whispers) Cirrhosis--it's a disease of the  liver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Liver* killed him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Alcohol* killed him--he drank himself  to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But did you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely. It hardly mattered that I  knew him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know your mother better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, still whispers) She's dead now, too. She was a nanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a nanny do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks after other people's  children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you grow up around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She was an immigrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's an immigrant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone not from Maine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orphanage in moonlight. Not a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are chasing a ball near the incinerator. A VERY FRIGHTENED GIRL---not one of the orphans--is lying next to the incinerator. Edna kneels by the strange girl, who cringes with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's going to hurt you, dear.  Have you come to visit us? We have  beds, you know. Have you had any  breakfast? What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl won't speak; when Edna touches the girl's forehe she pulls back her hand in alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna is holding the head of the frightened young girl. Th girl is feverishly hot and whimpering; she keeps looking her feet in the stirrups as if she's an animal caught in trap. Larch and Homer stand on either side of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her temperature is a hundred and  four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very gently) How old are you, dear? Thirteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl shakes her head. The pain stabs her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve? Are you twelve, dear? (the girl nods) You have to tell me how long you've  been pregnant. (the girl freezes) Three months?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another stab of pain contorts the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you *four* months pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl holds her breath while he examines her abdomen;  Homer very delicately examines the girl's abdomen, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Larch) She's at least *five*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl goes rigid as Larch bends into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear child, it won't hurt when I  look. I'm just going to *look*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer assists Larch with the speculum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me: you haven't done something  to yourself, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you go to someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he was a doctor. I would  never have stuck that inside me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuck *what* inside you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer holds the girl still--she is babbling on and on whi Larch is examining her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't me! I would never do no  such thing! I wouldn't stick that  inside me! It wasn't me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch, his wild eye peering into the speculum, makes an  audible gasp from the shock of what he sees inside the gi Larch tells Homer to have a look. Larch then whispers  something to Edna; she brings the ether bottle and cone  quickly. Larch starts putting the cone in place, over the nose and mouth of the frightened girl. Homer bends to the speculum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the twelve-year- old) Listen, you've been very brave. I'm  going to put you to sleep--you won't  feel it anymore. You've been brave  enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer stares into the speculum; he closes his eyes. The g is resisting the ether, but her eyelids flutter closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a heavy sedation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You *bet* it's a heavy sedation! The  fetus is unexpelled, her uterus is  punctured, she has acute peritonitis,  and there's a foreign object. I think  it's a crochet hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer has pulled off his surgical mask. He leans over the scrub sink, splashing cold water on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer) If she'd come to you four months ago  and asked you for a simple D and C,  what would you have decided to do?  *Nothing*? *This* is what doing  nothing gets you, Homer. It means  that someone else is going to do the  job--some moron who doesn't know  *how*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, furious, leaves the operating room. Edna lifts the girl's eyelids for Larch so that he can see how well unde the ether she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd come to *me*, dear child.  You should have come to me, instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer storms down the hall, then stops, pulling off his w coat. Angry, pacing, he kicks at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster and Homer are digging the pit. Larch paces by the  coffin of the 12-year-old girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd she die of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inhales deeply) She died of *secrecy*, she died of  *ignorance*...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster nods, but he's totally bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer) If you expect people to be responsible  for their children, you have to give  them the right to decide whether or  not to *have* children. Wouldn't you  agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster doesn't get it. Homer has heard this too many time he rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about expecting people to be  responsible enough to control  themselves to begin with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about this child? You expect  *her* to be responsible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean her. I'm talking  about... adults. (annoyed) You know who I mean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch studies him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster is driving the old pickup truck, with the shovels a wheelbarrow in the back. Larch and Homer are in the cab they are being bounced all over the cab by Buster's wild  driving. Larch looks at Homer; he stares at him with a cu smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch says nothing. Homer gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) It's just a marvel to me that you  still have such high expectations of  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy I amuse you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer) Try to look at it this way. What  choice does Buster have? What are  his options? Nobody will ever adopt  him. (Buster considers  this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to look at it *this* way. Buster  and I are sitting right here beside  you. We could have ended up in the  incinerator! (Buster grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to be alive, under any  circumstances--is that your point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster is distracted; he drives the truck into a ditch an it bounces around, missing a tree by an inch. He is up on the road again in a few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to be alive... I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all distracted by a luxurious convertible that  overtakes them on the hill to the orphanage. The fast car driven by a handsome man in the uniform of the Army Air C a YOUNG OFFICER. From the passenger seat, a BEAUTIFUL YOU WOMAN smiles at them, rendering them speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The luxurious convertible (now parked) has drawn all the  orphans to it. The handsome young officer (WALLY) and the beautiful young woman (CANDY) stand confused by the car;  they are surrounded by the curious orphans, with whom the are painfully self-conscious. They are overly friendly to the children as they are anxious of Larch and Homer and B (in their gravedigging attire), who are getting out of th truck. Nervously, Wally gives the children chocolates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many children. Are they all  orphans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this *is* an orphanage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids climb into Wally's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they're getting into the car...  watch your fingers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly tugs on Candy's dress, staring up at her, his face  already smeared with chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) You are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (good with kids) The best? Wow! The best at *what*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the best one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly's nose is streaming snot. Candy kneels beside him a holds her handkerchief to his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, blow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly tries to talk while she's holding his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really *am* the best, I just have  a cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blow! There, I bet that feels better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffs) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other orphans are dying with envy--Candy is so beauti (Some, like Buster, are torn between Candy and the car.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly, come here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Larch) *Tell* them! I'm the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virtually all the orphans have climbed into Wally's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wally) I'm sorry. They're not used to seeing  a car like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay--I don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch, scowling, presents himself to the new couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We brought some chocolates for the  kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (witheringly) Chocolates. How *thoughtful*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch picks up Curly and carries him toward the boys'  division.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the best! *Tell* them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the best, Curly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is seated in the desk chair. The impressive couple in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Mrs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy. Candy Kendall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally jumps up to his feet to shake Homer's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally. Wally Worthington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally sits down. The three sit still for an awkward momen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Candy) How many months are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer writes on a piece of paper. Candy and Wally exchang worried look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, now, uh... you're not... I mean,  do *you* do the--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Dr. Larch will be performing the  procedure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Ah, well... okay. Good! I just  wondered...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna pokes her head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Homer. Dr. Larch said  this one is your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna quickly sees that all three of them have misundersto her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear--I'm sorry. I meant the  circumcision. That boy you delivered  on Tuesday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Fine. Have you prepped him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy and Wally can't conceal how impressed they are with the young Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer walks down the corridor, dressed in his operating g as the door to the O.R. opens and Wally stumbles out,  hurriedly opening a window. Wally breathes deeply to rega his composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was the ether--the smell  got to me. (pause) God. This is all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna comes down the hall with a dirt-stained, crying Curl who's covering one eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the din) Steerforth got into the pantry--he's  eaten all the pie dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) He wasn't sharing it, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's down the hall, throwing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer nods to Edna, who is marching off with Curly. Wally smiles at Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of plane are you flying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A B-24 Liberator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liberator...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you enlisted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wouldn't take me. I'm Class IV-- I've got a heart defect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really! Is it serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not serious. I'm just not  supposed to get excited. You know-- no strain, no stress. I try to keep  calm all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally hears Homer's facetiousness--how tired he is of his heart condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well. I don't imagine there's  any strain or stress around *here*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer appreciates the joke. The door to the operating room that Wally exited opens in the corridor; Candy is being wheeled out on a gurney by L and Angela. Wally rushes to Candy's side. Homer follows  slowly. Candy is groggy, coming out of the ether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is she doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slurred speech) Boy or girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nothing--it's all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all over, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk Candy on her gurney. Homer looks after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slurred speech) I would like to have a baby, one  day. I really would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, of course--you can have as many  children as you want. I'm sure you'll  have very beautiful children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch wheels Candy behind a curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have Princes of Maine! You'll  have Kings of New England!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch has a different tone of voice when he speaks to Wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suggest you find yourself some  fresh air, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally is left alone in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cranked at three-quarters, Fuzzy sits in bed, wheezing an coughing. He's drawing with great intensity, using crayon on a piece of paper held by a clipboard. Homer sits on th end of Fuzzy's bed, cleaning up Steerforth. Homer pauses look out of the window; he sees Wally, dashing and spotle in his uniform beside his flashy car. A life Homer might  have had crosses his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, when is Halloween?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer turns to Fuzzy, who holds up his picture--a big pum with a jack-o-lantern face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) Uh... it's the end of October.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks at Fuzzy; his little body is working hard jus to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a few months away, Fuzz. (to Homer) I still don't feel so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Oh. It's the best time! How come we  only get pumpkins once a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuzzy coughs and coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get too excited, Fuzzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't we have pumpkins for  Christmas, too? We don't get any  good presents at Christmas, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks out the window at Wally again. His decision f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer approaches the flashy car, where Wally is still pac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has anyone offered you anything to  eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, someone did. I just didn't  think I could eat anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awkward silence, which Homer covers by examining the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to sound casual) I wonder if you might give me a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure! Be glad to! Uh... a ride where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unprepared) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're heading back to Cape Kenneth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer nods, but he has no idea where Cape Kenneth is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cape Kenneth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer runs up the stairs, two steps at a time; he races i a corridor at full speed, exhilarated. Suddenly Dr. Larch appears in front of him. Homer stops abruptly, out of bre unable to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Homer stands guiltily, Larch rifles through an X-ray f holding various X rays up to the lit screen. He quickly f the one he's looking for, attaching it briefly to the scr for a confirming look--a heart X ray, which Larch waves a Homer as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Doubtless you'll let me know what  immensely worthwhile or at least  *useful* thing it is that you find  to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (restrained) I wasn't intending to leave here in  order to be entirely useless--I expect  I'll find some ways to be of use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other parts of the world, I suppose  there are other ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still restrained) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blows up) Are you really so *stupid* that you  imagine you're going to find a more  gratifying life? What you're going  to find is people like the poor people  who get left here--only nobody takes  care of them as well! And you won't  be able to take care of them, either.  There's no taking care of *anybody*-- not out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling trapped) You know I'm grateful for everything  you've done for me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) I don't need your gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch hands Homer the heart X ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) I don't need this--I know all about  my condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your heart--you ought to take  it with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera closes on Homer with the X ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster and Mary Agnes are serving the evening meal while  Larch rails at Angela and Edna, who are helping Buster an Mary Agnes. The sound of children in the dining hall is  intermittent and chaotic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going where? Does he have a plan of  some kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will he be back soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! He's just leaving-- (to Angela) you're the one who says he needs to  see the world! (to Edna) *That's* what he'll do--he'll see  the world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) He's leaving...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll need clothes... some money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him try to *make* some money!  That's part of "seeing the world,"  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Oh, just stop it! You knew this was  going to happen. He's a young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost breaking) He's still a boy--out in the world,  he's still a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just find him some clothes, Wilbur.  He could use some clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera closes on Larch, fighting tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is packing his things--we see the heart X ray, and  some photos of Larch and Edna and Angela. Larch approaches Homer with a small bundle of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently, almost  reverently) I think these will fit you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is grateful and ashamed. Before he can speak, Edna there--a wad of bills in her hand. She tries to put the m in his pocket; when he refuses it, she simply puts the mo in his open suitcase, stuffing the bills under his clothe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll need some money--just a little  something, until you find a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch and Edna retreat from him, humbly, as if they were servants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Homer puts his stuff in the truck of Wally's car, Ange can't resist touching his face. She is too upset to speak From a window, Larch is watching the departure. He sees H saying goodbye to the children, embracing them. From another window, Fuzzy just stares. (Of course he's  coughing.) We see Wally carrying Candy to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggy) I'm okay--I can walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you to walk--I want to  carry you. Should I put the top up?  It might get cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--keep it down. I want to feel the  air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She speaks to Homer, touching his sleeve, like a sleepy  person, as Wally puts her gently in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still groggy) Coming with us? It's always a good  idea to have a doctor along for the  ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer gets in the passenger seat beside Wally, who starts the car; suddenly there is Curly. Homer can't look at Cur who looks betrayed. Edna picks up Curly and carries him t the passenger-side window. Curly is sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go, Curly. I'm sorry. (to Edna) I couldn't find Buster. Will you  tell him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't finish what he has to say. Edna kisses him good- bye. From the window, Larch watches the car leave. Buster, whittling a stick, isn't watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is quiet as the journey gets underway. Wally keeps  glancing at Candy in the rear-view mirror; she seems dist lost in thought. Homer is taking everything in--the speed the road, the wind in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela speaks to the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us be happy for Homer Wells...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the girls' washroom, in front of the mirror by the row sinks, Mary Agnes is repeatedly slapping her face. Angela benediction to the boys plays Over this scene of violent  self-abuse. Except for the sound of the slaps. Mary Agnes doesn't make a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer Wells has found a family. Good  night, Homer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Homer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his bed, Larch is taking ether. We hear the refrain fr the boys in the bunk room Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Homer! Good night, Homer!  Good night, Homer Wells!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio is playing. Candy is lying down, her knees draw up, in the backseat; she appears to be asleep, oblivious Homer and Wally's conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, the Army has given me leave  twice. First when my father died,  and now I'm on leave to help my mother-- I'm just trying to get her ready for  the harvest. She's no farmer. Apples  were my dad's business. And with the  war on, she's short on pickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy's eyes are open but her voice is groggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer) Wally thinks apples are boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer) I never said they were boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said, "Apples aren't exactly  flying."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they aren't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks back at Candy. Her eyes close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'd probably like the apple  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a little overqualified, aren't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. I need a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only jobs are picking jobs.  Picking apples is truly boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy's eyes snap open and she sits up a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There! You said it was boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, *picking* them is! It's about  as exciting as... walking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy seems irritated with Wally. Homer tries to engage h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your family in the apple business,  too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I work there--I like it. My  dad's a lobsterman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen a lobster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen the ocean, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) You've never seen the *ocean*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer shakes his head, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not funny... that's *serious*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is parked at the side of the road. Wally is half- hidden behind a tree. Candy and Homer are left alone in t car; there's an awkward silence as Homer pretends not to  hear Wally's excessive peeing. Suddenly Candy starts to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't have a baby with someone  who's leaving me--I didn't know what  else to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is a doctor--he's used to postabortion reactions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to be dropping bombs on  Mandalay! They're going to be shooting  at him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mandalay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't have a baby alone. I don't  even know if he's coming back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't, really. Wally returns. Wally leans over Candy hug her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, honey... of course I'll come  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy pounds on his chest with her fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't *know*, Wally. You have no  *idea*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally backs away. Candy sobs uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay away from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally signals to Homer to get out of the car. Later, Wally and Homer stand outside the car, overhearing Candy's weeping. Homer is smoking nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strictly medical) This is all normal. Don't worry. The  abortion procedure... it affects  you. It's the ether, too. It'll take  a little time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't *have* any time. There's a  *war*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all very normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally looks at Homer, who takes a nervous drag on his  cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to cut that shit out--it's  terrible for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks at Wally; he sees the authority in his eyes.  Homer drops his cigarette and puts it out with his foot. They notice that Candy has stopped crying. Wally finds Ca asleep in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lone car on the road. Snatches of war news from the r are the only sound as the headlights illuminate the dark  highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is parked, with Homer sleeping in it alone. The s of the ocean increase as Homer opens his eyes. Homer gets out of the car and walks toward the beach, enchanted. The it is: his first view ever of an ocean, the horizon, the glimmering on the water. Candy is lying on a blanket in t sand. Wally is throwing rocks in the water. Homer takes i all in. When Candy calls for him, Homer walks up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little worried about the... (she gestures below  her waist) ...about how much bleeding is okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It should taper off tomorrow, but it  can come back again. You have cramps? (Candy nods) They'll ease up, almost entirely. As  long as the bleeding isn't heavy,  it's normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A football comes flying through the air toward Homer; it  bounces off his chest. Wally laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning the football) Give it here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer throws the football; it's clear he's never thrown o before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was *that*?! Come over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer runs over to Wally, who proceeds to show him how to pass the ball. Snatches of his instruction drift to Candy who closes her eyes. "Put your fingers on the laces--no, rests in your palm, like this! You want the laces up--yes like that!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Wally sit on the beach a short distance from Ca blanket. She appears to be asleep. Wally looks in her  direction before he speaks to Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called the Burma run. It's about  a seven-hour round-trip flight between  India and China.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally draws a crude map in the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Burma run" because you fly over  Burma...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *And* over the Himalayas. That's  called flying over the hump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Candy's face: she's not asleep; she's listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what altitude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got thirty-five minutes to climb  to fifteen thousand feet--that's the  first mountain pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks at Wally, thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What lousy luck--I mean your orders...  to draw an assignment like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conspiratorially) Actually, I volunteered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is shocked; he looks back at Candy, lowers his voic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the flying, right? You love to  fly, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally nods; he also gives a look in Candy's direction bef he responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the bombing, too. But there's  also the Himalayas--they have the  most wicked air currents in the world.  I wouldn't miss flying there for  anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer's smile suggests that he's impressed, but that he  wouldn't have Wally's enthusiasm for the task. Wally laug and puts his hand on Homer's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, look... if you're serious about  wanting a job, picking apples isn't  that boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I would love that, Wally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is parked at a lobster pound. Homer sits in the c watching Wally carrying Candy's bag to the door. Candy st outside the car; she shakes Homer's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'll see you around the  orchards. Thanks for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure... I'll see you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy turns and heads toward the house to catch up with W A lobsterman in his boat is approaching the dock. It's RA Candy's father. Candy waves. "Hi, Daddy!" Homer glances a Candy and Wally on the dock, kissing good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) I love you, Wally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too. See you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally drives up to the Worthington house; he gets out of car. Homer sits in the car, admiring the beautiful farmho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. You have to meet my mom. (conspiratorially) If it comes up, I've been at a  wedding. That's where I met you, at  the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer as never seen such a room: the sports trophies, the photos of athletic teams, and of Candy with Wally. Model  airplanes are everywhere. Mrs. Worthington's voice comes  from the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally? I expected you earlier...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She appears in the doorway of Wally's room. Mrs. Worthing (OLIVE) is an elegant, fiftyish New Englander, as handsom as Wally, but more reserved. She is surprised to see Home

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Homer Wells--he's the most  overqualified apple picker you'll  ever meet, but he's dying to learn  the apple business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally is taking his uniform off as he speaks, just droppi it on the floor as he quickly puts on some farm clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Homer Wells...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer has never met anyone like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Worthington starts picking up her son's uniform from the floor. She is politely curious about Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you a friend of the bride or  the groom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks confused; he seems to have forgotten about th alleged wedding. Wally puts his arm around Homer, urging into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is everybody's friend, Mom...  the bride's, the groom's, mine,  Candy's, *everybody's*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is embarrassed, but Olive is obdurately well-manner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, perhaps you'll come to dinner,  Homer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally calls to her as he pushes Homer down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight, Mom--he's got to meet  *Mr. Rose*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Wally get out of the jeep at the cider house, a barnlike building with adjacent sheds and, behind it, lin after line of trees--the apple orchards. Homer sees an outdoor shower where THREE BLACK MEN are  showering. It is a wooden stall that leaves the shower's  occupants visible above and below their midsections. A FO BLACK MAN is caught naked, running behind the cider house and out of sight as he wraps a towel around himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already used up the hot water!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're usin' my soap, ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't usin' no soap--it's too cold  to bother with soap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ain't never enough hot water,  soap or no soap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're migrants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no clue) Migrants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They pick fruit, all kinds.  They travel up and down the coast  with the seasons. (leaning close to  Homer) The trick to Mr. Rose is, you have  to let him be the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer wonders what that means as Wally reaches for the do of the cider house. Before Wally can knock, a pretty youn black girl, ROSE ROSE, bumps open the screen door with he hip and throws a bucket of water in the grass--almost hit Homer and Wally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sink's backed up again, Wally.  I thought you was gonna get me a  plumber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, this is Homer--Homer, this is  Mr. Rose's daughter, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty, ain't it? You a plumber?
