dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no--Homer is a new *picker*.  He's going to stay here with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gets the attention of the men on their way from the  showers. They walk over, towels around their waists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) He's stayin' *here*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen door swings open and shut again, startling the all, as MR. ROSE comes out of the cider house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That daughter of mine sure is Miss  Hospitality, ain't she, Wally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grinning, Mr. Rose shakes Wally's hand. Rose Rose goes ba inside the cider house as Mr. Rose shakes Homer's hand. H introduces himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got lots of experience pickin',  I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer's got no experience, Arthur,  but he's smarter then I am. He's a  fast learner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose looks briefly at the men, who wait for his react

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is history. Ain't that what  you're sayin', Wally? I guess we  makin' *history*... havin' this young  man stay with us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally slaps Homer on the back; he goes inside the cider h to help Rose Rose with the plumbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks at Mr. Rose for instructions. Mr. Rose stares back at him with his enigmatic smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. What should I do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out back, there's a shed. It's just  a mess. If that shed was better  organized, I could put my truck in  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks at Mr. Rose with an uncomprehending expressio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're as smart as Wally says,  you know you sometimes gotta do one  job before you do another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer thinks that over. Later, Homer is cleaning out the shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickers all sit down to supper around a picnic table. Homer with Mr. Rose, Rose Rose, and the other black picke Mr. Rose takes an apple from a bowl on the table. Then he pulls out a knife and opens it in one fluid motion; he's fast, the knife seems to come out of nowhere. He begins t peel the apple. Homer eyes Mr. Rose, but Mr. Rose's focus riveted to his apple and the long, perfect strand of peel dangling from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did a good job with that shed,  Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peaches breaks the awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a name is Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the name of a cat. Originally.  Well, not *originally*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer decides to stop. Another silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now--we all got names, sensible  or not. (to Homer) Peaches is from Georgia, where we  met him pickin' peaches. He's still  better with peaches than hs is with  apples. (Peaches grins) Jack here is new. And this here is  Hero, 'cause he was a hero of some  kind or other once. Ain't that right,  Hero?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some disrespectful suggestions from the pickers concerning what his heroism might have been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this here sensitive-lookin' fella  is Muddy. The less said about Muddy,  the better. Ain't that right, Muddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muddy scowls at Homer, but he smiles at Mr. Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer unpacks his suitcase. (His bed should be nearest Mu and Mr. Rose's.) Jack lies on his bed, smoking. Muddy, al smoking, is sitting on his bed, sharpening a knife. Hero Peaches are playing cards on one of their beds. Mr. Rose finishing shaving. Rose Rose watches Homer unpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got a picture of your heart  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up the X ray, in order to show her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a little something wrong  with it. Just this part here--the  right ventricle. It's slightly  enlarged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, so what. It's nothing serious,  really. Just a small defect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's big enough to keep you out of  the war, I suppose. Ain't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose picks up the book that Homer has put on the bed She studies the cover; it's "Great Expectations" by Charl Dickens. She puts it down, restlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They told me I was too old to serve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They told Muddy his feet was too  flat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody laughs, except Muddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peaches) And you was "generally unfit," as I  recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finished unpacking, Homer sits on his bed; he picks up "G Expectations" and begins to read. Rose Rose sits down nex to him, watching him read. Homer notices her interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like to read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) I can't read. Nobody taught me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer smiles politely and goes back to his book. Rose Ros keeps looking over his shoulder at the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the page) What does it say there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks around at the pickers lying in their beds,  smoking, listening. (Like bedtime stories at the orphanag he thinks; however, the picker's attitude is suspicious,  reserved.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "I looked at the stars, and considered  how awful it would be for a man to  turn his face to them as he froze to  death, and see no help or pity in  all the glittering multitude."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks up; there's no response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rose Rose) More?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some muttering, some giggling, mostly silence. Rose Rose  wants more, but suddenly Jack jumps out of bed and stomps the kitchen end of the cider house, where a piece of pape is tacked to the wall. Jack is talking to Homer all the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you're the one who's smart  enough to read... what's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack points at the piece of paper. Homer gets up and look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a list of rules, it seems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the men groan--Jack swears and Peaches laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Whose* rules?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're for us, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on and read 'em, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "One. Please don't smoke in bed."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late for that one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the smokers laugh and cough in their beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncharacteristically  blunt) Stop it, Homer. They aren't our rules.  We didn't write them. I don't see no  reason to read them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose stomps back to her bed. Her father absently sna his towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody is asleep, except Homer. He is staring at the  ceiling in the quiet semi-darkness, the book lying on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distant echoing) Good night, you Princes of Maine!  You Kings of New England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch is standing in the doorway to the boys' room; h closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, on his bed, closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch lies in bed with his eyes open. (No ether.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cider house and the apple orchard in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally in his farm clothes at the wheel of the Jeep--he is racing through the orchards, dodging trees, with Homer in the passenger seat, hanging on for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember this! In the morning, when  the tall grass is wet, you can make  the Jeep slide on the grass. Can you  feel it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is excited as Wally weaves among the trees--faster faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost like flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the trees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trees are flak--antiaircraft  fire from those geeks on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally brakes hard. The Jeep comes to a stop in the packin house area. Candy has been waiting on the loading platform. The picke are working in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively to Candy) I was just showing Homer the  orchards... kind of a geography  lesson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (good-naturedly) I know what you've been doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls an apple branch, with an apple to two, out of t vehicle's grille--or else the branch is wedged in the fro bumper or headlight area. Candy playfully starts poking W with the branch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wally) You've been giving him a *flying*  lesson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing her) He *loved* it! (to Homer) Didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally gets the apple branch away from Candy. He pins her  arms at her sides--he hugs her, kisses her. She doesn't  struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing to Homer) He thinks people *like* to get whacked  by branches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Homer* liked it! (to Homer) Didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. There's no stress or  strain around here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh. Homer observes the happy couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is walking with Wally and Candy. The orchards are  beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much activity: the pickers are unloading apple crates fro full flatbed trailer. An angry-looking VERNON gives Homer evil glare. Homer spills some apples lifting the crate to the loading platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose takes Homer aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Vernon. You best stay away  from him until he gets to know you  better--then you best stay away from  him *more*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally, in full uniform, appears from inside the packing h he calls for Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out lieutenant's calling you, Homer.  Mind your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer smiles are runs toward Wally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Wally walk through the packing house, where the HEFTY, LOUD WOMEN sort through the apples rolling by on t conveyor tracks. Wally snatches an apple from one of them giving it to Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer) You getting along okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Homer can answer, the women interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is that Candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she leave you, Wally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally makes an effort to introduce Homer, but he's  interrupted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally, you can marry Debra if Candy  leaves you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally's gonna marry *me* if Candy  leaves him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can marry all three of us, Wally!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can take turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally puts his hand to his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You girls make it hard for a guy to  go off to war. (points to Homer) But I'll leave my best man here to  pinch-hit for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the women are left behind giggling, Wally continues ta to Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... I'm shipping out sooner than I  thought. I just wanted to be sure  you were settled in--and happy enough,  considering... (grabbing another  apple from a crate) Are you bored stiff? Or can you stick  it out for a bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... actually, picking apples is as  much excitement as I want for a while.  I'm grateful for the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his hand on Homer's  shoulder) You're the one who's helping *me*,  Homer. You're going to give my mom a  little peace of mind while I'm gone.  Candy, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure... that's good, then. (awkward pause) All I mean is, I'm lucky I met you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Homer. *I'm* the  lucky one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer shakes his head. Wally stops walking; they both sto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more serious) You want to fight about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is unfamiliar with this kind of kidding around; at  first he is startled, but then he laughs. Wally laughs, t They shake hands. Mr. Rose calls out to Homer from the tractor. The pickers are impatiently waiting for him on the flatbed; they're g back to the orchard. Homer has to run to catch up to them He jumps on the flatbed; he sees Wally waving good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High up in a tall tree on a couple of ladders, Mr. Rose a Homer are picking side by side. Mr. Rose is picking with  high-speed perfection, but Homer is slower and fumbling-- drops an occasional apple to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pickin' more cider apples then  anythin' else. Them drops is good  only for cider. And you pickin' the  stems with the apples only half the  time. They good only for cider, too-- if you don't pick them stems. (Homer watches him) The rule is, you wanna pick the apple  *with* the stem, Homer. And see  here... see that *bud* that's just  above the stem? That's the bud for  *next year's* apple--that's called  the *spur*. You pick the spur, you  pickin' two years in one--you pickin'  next year's apple 'fore it have a  chance to grow. You leave that on  the branch, you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer nods; he picks more carefully, with more concentrat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approvingly) That's better. I can tell you got  yourself some education. Them's good  hands you got, Homer. Them hands you  got, they know what they're doin'-- ain't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer can see over the apple mart parking lot from the to of the tree. He can see the driveway of the Worthington h where Candy and Olive are saying a tearful good-bye to Wa Distracted, Homer drops another couple of apples, which M Rose observes with a wry smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilbur! Wilbur!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch is doing something at his desk when Angela comes in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilbur, you should read this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch stares at Angela, who holds a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from the Board. Another letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch stands in front of a mechanical drawing easel. works intently with a calligraphic pen, but we don't see  what he's working on. Angela and Edna sit at the desk; th looking over the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting the letter) Uh... "merely suggesting that some  new blood might benefit you all...  someone with new ideas in the  obstetrical and pediatric fields." (she looks up at Larch) I think they're just testing some  ideas for our next meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Holtz seems nice. I think he  only wants to help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a goddamn psychiatrist--of  *course* he wants to "help"! He'd be  happy if he could help *commit* me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that Mrs. Goodhall you have to  be careful of, Wilbur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One has to be more than "careful" of  Mrs. Goodhall--she has sufficient  Christian zeal to start her own  country! I'd like to give her a little  ether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch puts down the pen, comes around the easel, opens a  drawer in a filing cabinet, and hands Edna a folder conta a few cleanly typed pages. Larch returns to the easel, to his painstaking work. Edna opens the file; as she and Ang read the contents, Larch recites from memory as he works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Homer Wells, born Portland, Maine,  March 2, 1915..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer was born *here*, in, what was  it, 1922?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...graduated Bowdoin College, 1935,  and Harvard School of Medicine, 1939."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is *your* life story, Wilbur!  You just changed the dates!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "An internship and two years of  training at the Boston Lying-in,  South End Branch. For his age, he  was judged an accomplished  gynecological obstetrical surgeon;  he is also experienced in pediatric  care..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You *invented* him! You've completely  made his up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you understand? The board is  going to *replace* me! That's what  the "new blood" is *for*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean they'll replace you with  someone who won't perform abortions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Well, we can only guess about that,  Edna. They *are* against the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These *credentials* are against the  law!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all know who trained Homer--his  credentials are as good as mine are.  Don't you be holy to me about the  *law*! What has the law done for any  of us here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna and Angela think this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points at file) So here is my candidate. What do you  think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about school records? Homer  doesn't have any *diplomas*...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch turns the easel around. Attached is a parchment hea "HARVARD MEDICAL SCHOOL"--it's a diploma-in-progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He *will* have them, Edna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women are shocked, awed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Wilbur, I don't know... (sudden thought) We don't even know where he is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer stands in front of a ladder that leans against the  cider house; he starts to climb up, drawn by the murmurin voices, the soft laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now. He's a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. We don't know what he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, you gotta watch your language  'round my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer arrives at the top and sees everyone sitting on a l plank, a bench attached to the apex of the roof--obviousl popular spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your manners? Make room for  Homer, so's he can enjoy the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What view?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peaches slides over and Homer sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we supposed to be up here? The  rules said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, you the only one who's read  them rules, so you the only one who  feels like he's doin' somethin' wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *What* view?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Muddy, we can look at all these  angry stars Homer's been readin' to  us about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter; Homer smiles, enjoying the teasing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing toward the  Worthington farmhouse) I bet the view looks better from the  Worthin'tons'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so, Jack? Well... I wouldn't  want to be in that Wally's shoes  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playfully, teasing  him) Daddy, I'd like to be in that Wally's  shoes *every* night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing her back) You lucky you in your work boots  tonight, girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's lucky about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose is being physically affectionate with her fathe lightly punching his arm, rubbing the top of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where that Wally is tonight,  darlin'? He's up there in them angry  stars. (gesturing at the  dark sky) He's flyin' all around up there...  with them Japs shooting at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look up, imagining that. Homer more than the oth Rose Rose, looking thoughtful, rests her head on her fath shoulder. They are completely natural together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and the pickers are loading crates of apples into a shipping truck. Olive and Candy are consulting some paper (the shipping tally) on a clipboard; Mr. Rose is standing beside them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all on board, Mrs. Worthin'ton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Arthur. (see is looking at  Homer) And how is our Homer working out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She catches Homer's eye; he smiles, then joins them. Mr.  Rose puts his arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's a smart young man, most of  the time--Wally was right about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive is looking over the rest of the picking crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No rotten apples?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it's an old way of  speaking that they  have) No, no--not this year. Well... maybe  we got *one*, but it ain't Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means Jack, who gives Olive and Candy and Mr. Rose a  furtive look. Olive smiles at Rose Rose, who comes up to and Candy. Olive touches Rose Rose with affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose... dear girl, I'm sure I can  find you some other clothes. (to Candy) You must have some things that would  fit her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy takes Rose Rose by the shoulders and turns her arou Rose Rose is enjoying this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a *ton* of things that would  fit you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, Candy--this girl don't  need no more clothes, not for pickin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts leading his daughter away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charming) Arthur, there's no such thing as a  young woman who's got all the clothes  she needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive waves good-bye as she moves toward her car. Candy t to Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Not bored yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm *never* bored! It's all very...  different for me... here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer has the hardest time looking at Candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... have you been *feeling* okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm not thinking about Wally.  I'm not good at being alone. (realizing) Oh, goodness. You meant... yes, I'm  fine. I... (struggling to change  the subject) ...I don't suppose you've seen a  lobster yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer shakes his head. He looks at the tractor and the em trailer. Mr. Rose and the pickers are just watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more seriously) You have to come to my dad's lobster  pound and see one, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks toward the pickers sitting on the flatbed whe he hears the tractor start. Candy follows his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think Mr. Rose would leave  without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose gestures for Muddy to drive off; the tractor tra pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer has to run to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Come next week!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps on the back of the departing flatbed between Mr. Rose and Rose Rose, as Candy watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An anxious-looking WHITE PLUMBER is fixing the kitchen si while the pickers (in their towels) stand around and watc Homer is putting on his best shirt. Peaches admires the s as Rose Rose cooks the night's supper on the wood stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa--look at that Homer! He's gettin'  all dressed up for supper tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't gettin' dressed to have  supper with *us*, Peaches!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickers all look at Homer, who looks guilty as he lea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the plumber) Don't let us make you nervous or  nothin'--we know you gotta job to  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we can wait all night for the  water to come back on--you just go  on and take your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer pedals a bicycle down a dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray holds a lobster up to the camera. We see the old-fash wooden pens, floating dockside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Ray and Candy go up the gangplank from the dock the lobster pound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're the garbage-eaters of the  ocean's floor. The seagulls clean up  the shore. The lobsters clean up the  bottom of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They eat everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything that falls to the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time somebody ate *them*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Candy) I was lookin' for Wally's letter. I  was gonna show it to Homer... (to Homer) They made him a captain already-- *Captain* Worthington!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, it's a letter to *me*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mentions Homer, too, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) Wally said to say, "Hello."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (equally awkward) Oh! That's... nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer) Wally said the most spectacular hits  were in the oil fields at Yenangyat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, through the window of the lobster pound, we see th eating lobster around a kitchen table. Laughter and some  unclear dialogue drift to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the bicycle stowed in the trunk, Candy is driving Ho back to the cider house. They pass a drive-in movie theat the marquee announcing "CLOSED FOR THE SEASON." Homer sta in awe at the giant blank screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A movie *outside*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But it's closed all the time  now, because of the blackout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People watched the movies in their  cars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) When they watched at all. Do you  like movies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! I've only seen one, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy looks at him; he isn't joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen only one movie? Which  one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "King Kong". It's really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen "King Kong" since I  was a kid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer laughs a little self-consciously; around her, he fe like he's *still* a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one table, the children are happily eating apples; a f of the kids are stuffing apples from a big bowl into thei pockets. At another table, Larch, Edna, and Angela sit ar an open packing crate of apples. Larch takes a bite from apple and spits it out. Angela takes the apple out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a pie apple, Wilbur. Homer  said you're not supposed to eat it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela hands him another apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he's an apple expert, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela gives him a critical look as Larch takes a bite ou of the new apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Oh my, yes! This is a *far* superior  taste--and crisp, too! You know, so  many apples are disappointingly mealy.  I wonder of most of the apples in my  life weren't meant for pies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilbur, he picked them for us  himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You don't find it depressing that  Homer Wells is picking apples?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Edna and Angela glower at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or that he can't be bothered to write  us a proper letter? A dissertation  on apples, we don't need!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) He probably doesn't make much money  picking apples--he must have had to  pay to send them, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't worry, Edna, that he  doesn't have money. If he gets hungry,  he can pick his dinner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch angrily tosses the half-eaten apple into the garbag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilbur, it's a *gift*! How can you  be angry with Homer for sending us a  *gift*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch stares into space, depressed. Then he examines the  crate and finds the mailing label that says "OCEAN VIEW  ORCHARDS--CAPE KENNETH, MAINE." He rips it off, holds it triumphantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show him a *gift*! I'll give  him a gift he can *use*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch storms out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A newsreel from the war is playing on the screen--soldier marching, smiling, waving to the camera. Homer and Candy together watching. Homer is completely fascinated; Candy  watches Homer as much as the news. Her expression changes when the newsreel cuts to footage from an air raid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy and Homer walk out of the theatre, under the marque and past the poster for "Wuthering Heights."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) But you looked as if you liked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I *did* like it. All I said was,  "It's not 'King Kong'."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy makes a face, but in good fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First she loved him, then she didn't,  then no one else could have him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She *did* love him! (teasing him) How many women have you known?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is embarrassed; he ducks the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did she die of, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was torn apart! She died of a  broken heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer smiles and shakes his head; Candy starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the *medical* explanation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she was in a weakened  condition... (laughs) I don't know! What about "King Kong"?!  Is that medically possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer smiles; he knows she's teasing him, and he likes it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock serious) At least King Kong knew what he  *wanted*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy pushes him playfully. They're both having a good ti *too* good a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is picking apples in a big tree; Rose Rose is on a  ladder in the tree right beside him. She's picking about  twice as fast as he is, and he keeps dropping his apples. another tree, Muddy is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is you *doin'* with that Candy,  Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Mr. Rose) He's makin' history, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the surrounding trees, the other pickers laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't gettin' in no trouble, I  hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In adjacent trees, both Peaches and Hero are picking appl they can hear Homer and Rose Rose, too. (So can Mr. Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Candy--she's the nicest girl I  know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's about the most beautiful girl  I ever seen--I don't know if she's  the nicest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the nicest *and* the most  beautiful girl I've ever known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men *oooh* and *aaah* at Homer's announcement--Mr. Ro too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like you is in trouble  already, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right--that sounds like trouble  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you is. I know when people is  in trouble, and you is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera closes on Homer's face; he keeps picking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Homer Wells...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna and Angela face the Board of Trustees around a table Larch circles the table as everyone reads the contents of folder. Larch has provided a copy for each member. The th elderly gentlemen on the Board don't speak; they just nod their heads to everything Dr. Holtz or Mrs. Goodhall says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and his *pathetic* resume is the  best I've seen. Though I find it  hard to believe the Board would be  interested in this character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he looks like an excellent young  man, a first-rate candidate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks like a bleeding-heart  missionary *moron* to me, but that's  going to be the problem with any  doctor interested in coming here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *No*! I don't want to know him! He's  doing *missionary* work--in *India*!  I wrote him *weeks* ago, but he's  either too holy or too busy to answer.  Maybe he got killed in the war!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Steerforth bursts through the door, having been  pushed from behind by Mary Agnes. The two stop when they what's going on--not to mention Larch's stern expression. They back out. Mary Agnes winking at Dr. Holtz before the door closes. Mrs. Goodhall is ready to continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fail to see how someone courageous  enough to make a commitment to a  foreign mission is automatically to  be dismissed--that part of the world  requires precisely the kind of  dedication that is needed here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it *snow* in Bombay? One winter  here and we'll be shipping him south,  in a *coffin*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't think that a man who has  *served* under such conditions as  exist over there will be in the  slightest daunted by a little *snow*-- have you no idea how harsh and  primitive and full of *disease* that  part of the world is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I suppose we can look forward  to catching various diseases from  him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Dr. Larch, he seems exceptionally  qualified...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about his medical  qualifications. It's the *Christian*  thing that bothers me--I just don't  see it being of much *use* around  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) I fail to see how a little  Christianity could *hurt* anyone  here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I was just showing you this  guy as an example of what's available-- I didn't think you'd be interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're *very* interested!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, *very*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't be opposed to meeting  with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it wouldn't hurt to *meet*  him. What's his name again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Homer Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) I just hope he won't expect us to  say *Grace* all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three elderly gentlemen repeat the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a nice name, very New England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very *Maine*, a very *local*-sounding  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Very*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A song plays on the old phonograph as a happy Larch and A dance. Edna interrupts them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to ask you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna! Come dance with me! Let's be  foolish tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he *know* he's supposed to be  in India? Does he even *want* to  come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This causes Larch to take the needle off the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) He's a field hand! What could possibly  hold him there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain beats down on Olive's car. Homer gets soaking we as he leans in to talk to Candy, who's behind the wheel. Rose calls to Homer from the doorway of the mill room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose is instructing Homer as they stand bottling cide in their yellow slickers and rubber boots. Rose Rose is h down the pressboards; Muddy and Hero and Peaches are oper the grinder and the press. Jack is stirring the vat. In a defiant, contemptuous way, Jack keeps flicking the ash of his cigarette into the vat. This make everyone uncomforta only Mr. Rose doesn't appear to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cider don't have no taste till later  in October--it's too watery now,  when we're usin' just them early  Macs and them Gravensteins. You don't  get no *good* cider till you're  pickin' them Golden Delicious and  them Winter Bananas, them Baldwins  and them Russerts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the worms? Most of these  apples are the drops--off the ground,  right? There have to be worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of *course* there's worms, Homer!  And what is them worms, really? They  just *protein*, them worms! They is  *good* for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone but Jack laughs. He takes a last drag on his  cigarette, then deliberately drops it into the vat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That just ain't right, Jack--your  cigarette's gonna end up in nine or  ten gallons of this batch of cider!  That ain't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them people drinkin' that cider,  they don't know there's a cigarette  in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that hard to find it in  there, Jack--it'll take you just a  minute. You just gotta go fishin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean *swimmin'*. I ain't goin'  in that vat to fish out no cigarette!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business is you in, Jack? Just  tell me what your business is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks for a translation from the other men, who are  nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just say you're in the *apple*  business, man. That's the only  business you wanna be in. Just say  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack pulls a knife on Mr. Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers excitedly  to Jack) You don't wanna go in the knife  business with Mistuh Rose--just say  you're in the *apple* business, Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mr. Rose) What business are *you* in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never see Mr. Rose's knife. We see the men circle each other: Jack takes a swipe at Mr. Rose's head--then he ste back, his yellow slicker slashed open. His slicker is ope up, right up the middle. His shirt underneath the slicker slashed open, too--he feels his bare chest and stomach,  feeling for the cut. But there's no cut--Jack's not bleed he's not even scratched. Just his clothes have been slash

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the *knife* business, Jack.  You don't wanna go in the knife  business with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muddy turns Jack around and views his slashed clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky he didn't cut your  *nipples* off, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The good news, Jack, is you're half- undressed for *swimmin'*...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that cigarette ain't hard to  find when you're properly undressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack starts to undress for the vat. Mr. Rose ushers Homer and Rose Rose outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose has cut his own hand in the fight. Homer's  professionalism if offended to watch Rose Rose's amateuri efforts to stitch up her father's wound, but clearly this isn't the first time she's done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give men that. I know how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I suppose you is a doctor, Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need no "almost" a doctor,  Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer can't bear to watch Rose Rose at work with the need

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should drown that damn Jack in  the vat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, darlin'... Jack just needs  to know what business he's in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you really showed him, Daddy-- you just about cut your own hand  off, and all you cut off *him* was  his clothes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You oughta know you don't go to jail  for cuttin' a guy's *clothes*. Ain't  that right, Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer winces at the stitching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally's car comes bouncing along the ditches of the close drive-in. Homer is at the wheel; Candy calls out some dri instructions. The car comes to a stop next to a speakerpo Candy leans out; she grabs the speaker and hangs it on th window. Homer sits back and drapes his arms out the windo and over the seat. He feels great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a natural. You were born to  drive a car like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think? Maybe I was. (looks around) I love this place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks up at the giant movie screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen is enormous! Imagine King  Kong up *there*! Have you seen a lot  of movies here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... and no. When you come here,  you don't really care about the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer stares at Candy in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't care about the movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy looks at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you so crazy about the movies  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my favorite night at the  orphanage--movie night. We'd race  into the dining hall. Of course  everyone wanted to sit in front, so  we'd be packed in so tight you could  feel the kid next to you breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you were never lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. Growing up in an  orphanage, you're always lonely.  You're just never alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy is moved. Homer feels exposed; he tries to change t mood by making light of what he's said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not alone in the bathroom,  or... or in the shower... you're  never alone in wanting the last piece  of meatloaaf, or even in your own  bed on a cold morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't miss it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss things. I miss... people. (with certainty) I miss reading to the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you had so much *responsibility*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never *asked* for any  responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Privacy is exactly the point of drive- in movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you come here with Wally--to  *not* watch movies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the mention of Wally they both look a little self- conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes... movies mostly bore Wally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. (points to the speaker) So what is that--a radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The *speaker*. For the movie sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy looks at Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrunch down like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy scrunches down in her seat; Homer imitates her. Hom is focused on the giant screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you not *care* about the  movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just cuddle. You come to hug...  to kiss. You don't *come* here to  watch the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing her) That's what *I'd* come here for. I'd  watch the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with the right girl you wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer's expression changes from exhilarated to guilty. He leans back in his seat and looks straight ahead at the sc Candy tentatively leans her head on his shoulder. Homer l afraid to breathe. From behind, with her head on his shoulder, they look lik normal couple. We track in toward the huge screen until w see only the screen. There are shadows on the black scree Suddenly the movie "King Kong" appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "King Kong" is playing against the bare, white wall. Fuzz is very weak, but he smiles at the sight of the love-stru Kong holding the screaming Fay Wray in his giant hand. Dr Larch runs the projector; he sits close beside Fuzzy. Whe the film breaks in the predictable place, Fuzzy makes no  protest. Dr. Larch looks at Fuzzy, who has stopped breath his eyes are closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuzzy? Fuzzy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are alone in the dining hall. Larch has wheeled in F for a private viewing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster helps Larch lower the small coffin into the grave. The tiny gravestone says "F.S."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to tell the little  ones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell them Fuzzy was adopted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would the little ones believe  that *anyone* would adopt him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll believe it because they want  to believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we tell Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Homer wanted to know what was  happening here, he could pick up a  telephone and call us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys in their beds listen to Buster inventing Fuzzy's "family."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a family with a better  breathing machine then the one Dr.  Larch built.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch leans against the wall, covering his eyes, overhear the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family that adopted Fuzzy, they  *invented* the breathing machine.  It's their business... breathing  machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch pauses; he waits to see if they believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky Fuzzy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch almost breaks with a sudden sharp breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Fuzzy! Good night, Fuzzy!  Good night, Fuzzy Stone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the men sit at the picnic table eating their cornbread Rose Rose pours coffee. A jeep comes down the orchard roa toward them. It's Olive. Mr. Rose leads the "Good mornin' Mrs. Worthin'ton!" greeting. Olive has an armful of cloth and a fairly sizable package; she brings the latter over Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some mail for you, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer shakes the package; he puts the package beside the  table, unopened. Olive turns to Rose Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And some clothes for you, dear-- (nodding to the cider  house) let's go see if they fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose watches Rose Rose and Olive disappear into the c house. The other men view Homer's package with curiosity, especially Peaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you gonna see what it is, Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind your own business, Peaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Homer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer lies awake in bed; everyone else is asleep. Homer p the package out from under his bed, opening it just enoug to see what it is; then he shoves it back under his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beach at sunset. Candy and Homer, dressed for cooler  weather, are alone at the water's edge. From a paper bag, Candy is scattering some small, brightly colored pieces o broken glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you worried that people will  cut their feet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody will swim here until next  summer. By then, the water will have  rubbed the glass smooth against the  sand--there won't be any sharp edges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds and old piece of glass among the stones and she at the high-tide mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? That's last year's glass, or  from some year before. I put glass  here every year. The ocean makes it  beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy holds up a piece of glass to the sun for Homer to l at. The ocean is a gray-green color, the glass a paler sh of green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rubs the smooth piece of glass against his hand, then throws it toward the water. It falls short. Homer retriev it. Candy splashes him playfully. He chases her away from the beach, into the pine trees. Homer locks his arms arou her, from behind. He can't let go. She lets him hold her, then breaks his grip. She turns to face him. She is talle then he is, older, obviously more experienced. She initia the kiss. They drop to the ground right there; they make  love by the roots of the tree, Candy guiding him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come out of the woods, walking toward the car, Candy leading. We hear Candy talking just before we see her and Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (increasingly upset) *Nobody* volunteers for the Burma  run--he said so himself. And nobody  knows *me* better than him! So how  am I supposed to feel? He's a bomber  pilot and I'm just selfish, I know.  Well, I'm *not* a brave little girl  and I'm *not* sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits in the passenger seat, Homer in the driver's sea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I *know* this was right. (pause) I told you. I'm not good at being  alone. (pause; in a whisper) I told him, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer concentrates on starting the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating herself) I *know* this was right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their expressions, as the car pulls away, belie their wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Mr. Rose sit opposite each other at the picnic  table. Rose Rose stands behind her father, her hands on h shoulders, watching Homer snip out Mr. Rose's stitches--v quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down, Homer--don't be in such a  big hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is easy--I'm not hurrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still doin' it too fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Job done, Homer leaves the table and hurries to the bicyc pedaling away. Rose Rose watches Homer go, as Mr. Rose fl his healed hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in a big hurry, all right. I  told you he's in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy and Homer sit on the dock. Candy still seems to be  wrestling with her conscience. Homer throws snails in the sea. It's cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me. Do you want me to go?  Do you want me to stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *What* will be okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to wait and see. I think  that, for *everything* in life, you  have to wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer throws a snail with more force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just move on, get another job  somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray comes out onto the dock; he sees Homer throwing anoth snail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time you throw a snail off the  dock, you're makin' someone start  his whole life over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy throws a handful of snails into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we're doing the snails a favor,  Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks at the two of them; he sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gettin' late. I think I'll pack  it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods good night; he leaves. Homer looks expectantly a Candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just have to wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive and Homer sit at the dining-room table, the remnant of an apple pie in front of them. Homer is still eating.  Pictures of Wally are on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to hate it when Wally went  back to college--even when it was  just college! And this was when his  father was still alive... I hated it  even then. Naturally I hate this  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer nods in sympathy. His mouth is stuffed with apple p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I mean is... I would like it  very much if you thought you could  be happy here, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wiping his mouth) Mrs. Worthington, I feel I'm very  lucky to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not a lot of work in the  winter, and you'll have to tolerate  Vernon--even Wally despises him, and  Wally likes everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive's thoughts drift; her eyes look up at a photo of Wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Wally will be fine, Mrs.  Worthington--he seems indestructible  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) I don't know. (intently at Homer) Just promise me one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is tense. Does Olive suspect about Candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just promise me that, if there's a  blizzard, you'll move into Wally's  room until it's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both laugh, but Homer has a hard time looking her in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickers are moving out; the harvest is over. Olive an Homer stand near the door to the bunkhouse, talking--we c hear their conversation. Rose Rose and the other men walk past them, carrying the last of their belongings to the t Olive and Homer walk over to the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye. Have a safe trip home.  Thank you, again, for all your hard  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take care now, Mrs. Worthin'ton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Arthur. (she hugs Rose Rose) Homer, I'll see you tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive gets in her Jeep and waves as she drives off. The truck is packed. Muddy tugs on a rope that secures th load.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mr. Rose) We all set, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose nods and gets in behind the wheel. Rose Rose and Muddy get in next to him. The others are bundled up for t ride in the open back of the truck. As they're leaving, Homer waves good-bye--the pickers cal out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all take care of yourself, too,  Homer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see you next harvest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't freeze to death, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on and freeze to death if you  want to, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, Jack--that just ain't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just stay out of trouble, Homer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer stands looking after them, after they're gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is alone, rearranging his stuff--spreading out a bi making the place his own. (On the other beds, we see the  mattresses rolled up on the bare bedsprings.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you're staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer turns; he hadn't seen Candy come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive told me. (awkward pause) You might have told me yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just waiting and seeing. Like  you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles. He goes to her; they embrace. BEGINNING A MONTAGE OF THE NEXT NINE OR TEN MONTHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, drinking coffee, is writing a letter on a note pad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Dr. Larch, thank you for your  doctor's bag...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is learning how to "haul" a lobster pot with Ray an Candy's guidance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...although it seems that I will not  have the occasion to use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following Ray's example, Homer is trying to "disarm" the  lobsters' big claws by blocking them shut with the little wooden wedges. Roy works quickly, never getting pinched. Candy watches, Homer gets pinched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barring some emergency, of course. I  am not a doctor. With all due respect  to your profession. I am enjoying my  life here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Candy are naked. They have pulled two beds toge and made a double bed. He can't take his eyes off her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've looked at so many women... I  mean, I've seen *everything* about  them, *everything*... but I never  felt a thing. I felt nothing. Now...  with you... it *hurts*... to look at  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna and Angela and Larch are all reading Homer's letter, their lips moving silently as they read the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am enjoying being a lobsterman and  an orchardman--in fact, I have never  enjoyed myself so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive and Homer and Candy are playing a board game around the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is, I want to stay here. I  believe I am being of *some* use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna and Angela view him anxiously from the doorway as La furiously types and types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Homer, I thought you were  over your adolescence, that period  which I would define as the first  time in our lives when we imagine we  have something terrible to hide from  those who love us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy is singing to the car radio, as animated and happy we've ever seen her. Homer, driving, can scarcely keep hi eyes on the road; he has to keep looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it's not obvious to us  what's happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the radio playing (a popular song), Homer hops acros the bare floor, pulling on his boxer shorts; he opens the door to Olive, who's holding out an armload of blankets t him. He sheepishly thanks her. When Homer closes the door we see a hidden (and stricken) Candy, naked from their  interrupted lovemaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fallen in love, haven't you?  By the way, whatever you're up to  can't be too good for your heart.  Then again, it's the sort of condition  that can be made worse by worrying  about it. So don't worry about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vernon and Homer are working under an apple tree; they ar poisoning mice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Dr. Larch, what I am learning  here may not be as important as what  I learned from you, but everything  is new to me. Yesterday I learned  how to poison mice. You use poison  oats and poison corn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supper chaos--Buster and Mary Agnes are doing their best stop a food fight while Larch and Angela and Edna are  completely absorbed reading Homer's letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Field mice girdle an apple tree.  Pine mice kill the roots. I *know*  what you have to do--you have to  play God. Well... killing mice is as  close as I want to come to playing  God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Candy are watching "Rebecca".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I interfere? When absolutely  helpless women tell me that they  simply *can't* have an abortion,  that they simply *must* go through  with having another--and yet another-- orphan... do I interfere? *Do* I? I  do not. I do not even *recommend*. I  just give them what they want: an  orphan or an abortion. (close on Homer) You are my work of art, Homer.  Everything else has been just a job.  I don't know if you've got a work of  art in you, but I know what your job  is. You're a doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio is playing a slow, sexy dance number. The fat l from the apple mart are dancing as they paint the interio walls of the bunk house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know everything I know, plus  what you've taught yourself--you're  a better doctor then I am and you  know it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is finishing up painting the kitchen walls. When he gets to the list of rules, tacked on the wall, he removes the list and finishes painting under where the rules were

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to replace me, Homer!  The Board of Trustees is looking for  my *replacement*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of the ladies unroll the rolled-up mattresses on the  bare bedsprings, as Vernon enters with an armload of blan and pillows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't replace you! I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer holds up the list of rules, rereads it briefly; he  walks over to an unpainted beam, a support beam, and tack the rules on this beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer reads Larch's letter, sipping coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? I'm not 'sorry'! Not for  anything I've done. I'm not even  sorry that I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch sits on his ether-bed with a letter from Homer in h hand. He looks completely deflated. Angela is standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we may have lot him to the  world. He's not coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the newly painted, spruced-up cider house, Homer and C are dancing to another slow, sexy song on the radio. He i untucking her blouse, feeling under her blouse--she start to unbutton his shirt. They kiss while they dance. But th song changes abruptly on the radio to something fast and  silly. Homer responds to the music, dancing goofily--instantly o of the mood. Candy laughs, but she picks up a pillow and  swings it at him, hitting him. He dances away from her. S throws the pillow; he ducks--the pillow lands somewhere n the door. Now Homer grabs a pillow and chases her from be to bed. She shrieks--they're both laughing. They each gra pillow and stand toe to toe whacking each other, laughing all the while, until he pins her arms behind her and,  breathing hard--and despite the stupid music that broke t mood--they are passionately kissing again. The sound of a truck is sudden and loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose's truck has arrived. The pickers are hopping out the truck, grabbing their gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Hero and Peaches barge in, as Homer and C are struggling to return the pillows to the beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that Homer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muddy is right behind them. He picks up a pillow, off the floor, looking for which bed it belongs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that Candy, too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then comes Mr. Rose, slyly smiling, taking it all in--the no hiding what's going on. Homer and Candy are caught, th shirts untucked and half-unbuttoned--they're still out of breath. The pillows lie crazily on the beds, each one of  which has been stepped on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't this place look like home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It look nicer then home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you two been doin' to make  it look so nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose enters. She looks hardened, toughened--not happ She plops down her stuff on her bed, looking only at Cand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that Wally doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's fine! I just heard from  him. He's bombing all these places...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer tries to help out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) ...bridges, oil refineries, fuel  depots...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peters out, knowing how sick of hearing this Candy is. tries to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an uncomfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just wasn't up for the trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Jack just never knew what his  business was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One look at Muddy and we know something pretty bad happen to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickers on their ladders, all picking. Homer is now a good picker; he looks over at Rose Rose. She is slumped  against the ladder, not picking, completely ignoring an  argument beneath them in the aisle between the trees. (Mr Rose is checking over the apples Peaches has just picked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pickin' nothin' but cider apples,  Peaches--I hope you understand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't drops--I picked 'em off  the tree!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you pickin' 'em too fast--they  ain't no better than drops to me.  See that bruise, and that one? *Half*  of these is bruised! Look at this  one! It ain't got no stem! You might  as well *step* on 'em, too--they  only good for cider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the aisle between the trees, Homer and Candy are argui in one of the work vehicles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I'm having a good time?  Do you think I'm just *teasing* you?  Do you think I *know* whether I want  you or Wally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we should "wait and see." For how  long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up with Wally. I began my  adult life with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. That's all there is to it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! That's not all there is to it! I  love you, too--I *know* I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay--I know you do, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) It's a good thing I didn't have that  baby, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her sudden hardness leaves him speechless as they go thei separate ways. Candy drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast time at the picnic table. Rose Rose by herself, away from the table. She does not look well; she suddenly goes back inside the bunkhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after her) Ain't you eatin' with us, Rose? (to the men) She used to eat with us. Now we ain't  good enough for her, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't hungry, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't hungry every mornin' 'cause  she's sick every mornin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer gets up to take his dishes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Homer comes in, Rose Rose is throwing up in the sink

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, Rose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you must like watchin' me be  sick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like watching anyone be sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose lies down on her bed with the curtain open. The is something familiar about the way Homer approaches her  bedside; he does so with the authority of a doctor. He si on the edge of her bed with such complete self-assurance  that she doesn't protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many months are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just stares. But she doesn't stop him when he touches her abdomen. It's as if she knows that he knows what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not yet three months, are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. What do you know about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know more than I want to know about  it. Who's the father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't trouble yourself about it,  Homer--this ain't your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't look very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Happy*! What are you thinkin'? How  am I supposed to take care of a baby!  I can't have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, please listen. Whatever you  want to do, I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is taken back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I mean is, if you don't want  to... keep the baby, I know a place  where you can go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Daddy's gonna let me go  anywhere? I ain't going *nowhere*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rolls over on the bed, facing away from him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just go back to your  pickin', Homer? I can take care of  it myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, listen--don't *do* anything.  You know, I mean to yourself. Please  listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Homer! Is this a workin' day or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Candy are sitting at the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should take her to St. Cloud's.  That much is obvious, isn't it? Let  her make up her mind when she gets  there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her! She doesn't feel she can  do that. Something about her father  not letting her go anywhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we have to help her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to do *something*. Don't we? (beat) Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks out over the ocean; he remains unresponsive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose is setting the picnic table for lunch when Cand arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She keeps setting the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some more clothes for you-- I just keep forgetting to bring them  with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need no more clothes, thank  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Rose, I know what's going on. Homer  told me. I got pregnant, too--about  a year ago. (pause) I've been through this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't been through what I been  through, Candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't get it) Yes, I *have*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose dismissively waves her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the father, Rose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks at Candy and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to have the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose shakes her head again, more emphatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where you can go. Homer and I  can take you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't go nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose stays silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it the father? Does he know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose turns away from Candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
