dialogues.text: You can trust me. Is it Jack? It's  not Jack, is it? It's *Muddy*! Is it  Muddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost wistfully) No. It ain't Muddy. Muddy's just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose stops; she can't even continue setting the tabl Her voice turns bitter, despairing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure ain't Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, suddenly, is Mr. Rose, walking past them. He is  uncharacteristically tentative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his daughter) I'll be up top...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose leaves Candy and Rose Rose alone again. Rose Ros nods almost invisibly after her father. Rose Rose looks  pointedly at Candy, nodding. Candy slowly gets it. Mr. Ro is the father! Rose Rose lets that sink in; she keeps loo at Candy with an ashamed expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickers are at work, on their ladders, when Candy run down the aisle between two rows of trees. She stops at th bottom of Homer's ladder, out of breath. Muddy and Peache and Hero, in the treetops, are watching and listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't go to St. Cloud's!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Well, we can't force her. It's her  decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand! It's her  father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose *knows*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) He's the *father*! He's her baby's  father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickers can't help but hear this, too. Candy starts t leave, Homer running after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... *wait*! Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to keep her away from that  bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy leaves. Homer starts looking for Mr. Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling his enigmatic smile, Mr. Rose keeps slowly pickin while Homer stands at the foot of his ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see where you was pickin'  this mornin', Homer, but you musta  worked up a big appetite. You look  like you're serious about gettin' to  your lunch today!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose stops picking, his eyes darting to see who's aro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sleeping with your own  daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose, with deliberate slowness, comes down the ladder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slyly; still composed) I think you been stayin' up too late  at night, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're actually having sex with your  own little girl? Is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't nobody havin' *sex* with my  little girl, Homer--that's somethin'  a father knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying. How can you... with  your own daughter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose switches from sly to threatening in a split seco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, don't you know what business  you in? You don't wanna go into no  business with me, Homer--ain't that  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, cut my clothes. I've got other  clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose is indignant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a fine one to be talkin' about  lies. Shame! These people took you  in. That boy Wally's at *war*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That takes some of the steam out of Homer's superiority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's your *daughter*...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I *love* her! There ain't nobody  else gonna treat her as good as I  do! (looks away) I wouldn't do nothin' to hurt her,  Homer--you must know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer turns; he speaks over his shoulder as he walks away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's *pregnant*. Do you know *that*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By his expression--he looks as if he's been punched--it's clear that Mr. Rose didn't *know that*. The other pickers are on their way to lunch; it's obvious that Muddy, Peaches, and Hero already know that Mr. Rose sleeping with his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose is sitting at the picnic table when the pickers arrive for lunch, almost simultaneously with Homer. He lo at, then looks away from, Rose Rose. Mr. Rose is the last sit down at the table as a very tense, wordless lunch beg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is on a ladder picking apples. Muddy climbs a ladde on the other side of the same tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mess in this, Homer, if you  know what's good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long's this been going on, Muddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long enough. You ain't gonna stop  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muddy looks all around for Mr. Rose; then he gives Homer knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's my knife, Homer. It ain't  gonna do *me* no good. You give that  knife to Rose Rose, you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer nods, pocketing the knife. As Muddy climbs down and moves his ladder to an adjacent tree, he keeps talking to Homer until he disappears in the leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You best just watch you ass, Homer!  You don't wanna end up like Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer thoughtfully continues his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer lies awake in his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickers on their ladders in the trees; nobody is talk In the late sun, the leaves have a reddish, fiery glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's much colder; the pickers are on their ladders in the trees again, but they're dressed for the cold. Homer is h on a ladder; he turns toward the view of the Worthington  house when he hears a car come to a screeching halt in th driveway. Homer sees Candy get out of Wally's car; she le the door open and runs toward the house. Parked in front Wally's car is an Army Jeep, with an ENLISTED MAN leaning against it. The indifferent soldier smokes a cigarette as watches Candy run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer descends the ladder and runs for the house, down as aisle between the row of trees. The pickers watch him run

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera follows Homer into the Worthington house where, fr the front hall, he sees Olive and Candy (in profile) sitt on the couch. We can't see who's talking, nor do we recog the voice. As Homer comes into the living room, we see MA WINSLOW sitting in a chair (also in profile), talking to  Olive and Candy. Major Winslow is a smooth, handsome well-briefed officer the casualty branch of the Army Air Corps; he's done his  homework, but he's not all business. He's painfully aware the delicate nature of his report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the plane was hit, the crew  chief and the radioman jumped close  together. The copilot jumped third.  All on Captain Worthington's orders-- the captain was still flying the  plane. None of the men of the ground  could see the sky--that's how thick  the jungle was. They never saw the  plane crash--they never *heard* it  crash. They never saw Captain  Worthington's parachute, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was he missing for twenty days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the crew thought he'd gone  down with the plane. They were  hospitalized for almost a week in  China before they were flown back to  India. It wasn't until that they  sorted through their gear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares about their *gear*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three men jumped from the plane, but  they had four compasses with them.  One of the crew jumped with Captain  Worthington's compass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was in Burma for twenty days  without a compass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He followed the Irrawaddy River, all  the way to Rangoon. Somehow he managed  to avoid the Japs, but not the  mosquitoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's malaria?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's encephalitis B. He's recovering  at Mount Lavinia Hospital, Ceylon. (pause) Uh... Captain Worthington is  paralyzed. (Olive gasps) Waist down. He won't walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy stands and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Olive) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (asks the major) There are no autonomic effects, are  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Winslow has to consult his notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No autonomic effects... that's  correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will he be home, Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four weeks or so, right around  Halloween.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Candy are sitting in the parked car in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) There are no autonomic effects, just  the paralysis of the lower  extremities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy stares at him, uncomprehending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally can have kids, a normal sex  life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is throwing snails in the water. Candy sits on the en of the dock, slumped on Homer's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about him not needin' the friggin'  compass! How about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, *please*...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray knows that she wants him to leave. He shuffles off th dock, toward the house. He knows how they both must feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, kids. Don't catch cold-- it's gettin' cold already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer tries to cuddle closer, but Candy sits up, preoccup

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me. I'll do whatever you  want to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that like waiting and seeing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nothing is nothing. I want Wally  to come home. I'm afraid to see him,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (he kisses her) Is *that* nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't--that's something. Nothing  is nothing. (Homer's sad smile) Don't even look at me. I want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy buries her face in his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to do nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer holds her, doing nothing, while she sobs. As her cr subsides, Homer's thoughts are far away. With Candy slump against him, hugging him, he doesn't look at her; instead he looks out to sea and at the darkening coast, Candy's w resonating. An unfamiliar expression is on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling to himself) It's a tempting idea, I know... to  do nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy is silent. Homer feels strangely agitated; he shift his position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groans) Please don't move, don't go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overly genuine) *Go* anywhere? Of course not! That  would be *doing* something, wouldn't  it? We wouldn't want to *do*  something. Let's just sit here all  night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) If you're trying to be funny, Homer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated, too) I'm not trying to be anything--I'm  just doing nothing! If I wait and  see long enough, then--with any luck-- I won't *ever* have to make up my  mind! Decisions can be painful, after  all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy is angry; she gets to her feet and stares hard at h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! Just cut it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock surprise) You got up! You *did* something! If  you keep this up, you might be in  danger of making a *decision*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Homer, Wally's been  shot down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy sobs. Homer puts his face in his hands for a minute He regains his composure and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely contrite) I know, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling and sobbing) He's *paralyzed*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan; just the  facts) He's *alive*. He still loves you. (pause) So do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anguished) What do you want me to *do*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He faces away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with calm resolve) Nothing. You're not the one who has  to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is in semidarkness as he walks toward the cider hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta let me go, Daddy. Please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer walks faster. When he gets to the cider house, he s Mr. Rose and Rose Rose arguing. Rose is sitting on the  bicycle, a bundle of her clothes tied up behind the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't goin' nowhere in the middle  of the night, girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't your business no more, Daddy.  Please let me go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose starts to pedal away, but Mr. Rose stops her. S starts to struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey! Stop it. Maybe I can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to see Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just go inside, Homer. We don't  need no help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Homer. This ain't your  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to break free from her father and pedal away, b he stops her again. They keep struggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please listen to me! *Both* of you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forget yourself, Homer. This  here's my daughter! You got your own  mess to deal with--ain't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer steps between them, which makes Mr. Rose furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) What business is you in, Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose, I'm in the *doctor*  business. (to Rose Rose) If you want, I can help you. You  don't have to go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose and Mr. Rose stop struggling. Suddenly Homer is charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muddy, Hero and Peaches smoke in their beds. Rose Rose op her curtain and peers out from her bed. She gets up and g toward the kitchen area in her nightshirt; she stops at a unused bed, now covered with white rubber sheeting--Homer medical instruments are displayed and ready. Homer finish scrubbing his hands in the sink. His surgical mask is loo tied around his neck. Mr. Rose is looking at Homer's surgical instruments when  Rose Rose joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer) What's that? What's it called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One cervical stabilizer, two sets of  dilators--Douglas points. One medium- sized curette, one small; one medium  speculum, one large; two vulsellum  forceps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ain't no *almost* about this  stuff, Homer--ain't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer ignores him; he keeps naming his equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merthiolate, ether, vulval pads,  gauze--lots of gauze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it comes to this, you is the  real thing--is that what you sayin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks at Mr. Rose and Rose Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No *almost* about it--I'm a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer turns to Peaches, Hero, and Muddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muddy herds Peaches and Hero out of the bunkhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm stayin', Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Then you can be of use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose wears a surgical mask; he is sweating, even in t cold, and his eyes look stricken as he watches Homer, who performing the abortion. Mr. Rose holds the ether cone ov Rose Rose's face. He drips some ether from the bottle on cone. Cut quickly for Rose Rose's etherized face... to Mr. Rose eyes above his mask... to Homer working with his eyes tra on the speculum...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to Muddy and Peaches and Hero huddled under the overha roof in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose is having a hard time breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get some air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cider house in the rain. Mr. Rose staggers out; he st there in the rain, trying to regain his composure. He sta to scream. Another angle: huddled under the overhanging roof, Muddy Peaches and Hero are watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose, curled in a fetal position, listens to the rai on the roof. Candy sits on her bed beside her. She helps to sit up, to drink a glass of water; then Rose Rose lies down again. Rose Rose's expression never changes while Ca talks to her. Mr. Rose lies in his bed in the exact same  fetal position as his daughter; he too, is listening to C Homer is putting away his instruments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bleeding should taper off  tomorrow, but it can come back again.  The cramps will ease up, almost  entirely. The bleeding is usually  much lighter in two days. As long as  the bleeding isn't heavy, it's normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muddy enters the cider house from out of the storm. He gl at Candy and Rose Rose; then at Homer. Then he speaks to Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that Vernon--he keeps askin'  where you and Homer and Rose Rose is  at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell that Vernon to mind his own  business, Muddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him that you all is sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him what you want, Muddy--*you*  is the crew boss today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hero and Peaches, dripping wet, come inside. Peaches is  standing next to the list of rules tacked to the kitchen  support beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that. Them same damn rules  is tacked up again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer has finished putting his instruments away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you put them damn rules in  the wood stove, Peaches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the men are murmuring their approval of this idea, Ros Rose interjects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to hear what they are, first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men groan, but Mr. Rose won't oppose his daughter on  this subject--not this time. He just lies there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, let me hear what they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "One: Please don't smoke in bed."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard that one already, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Two: Please don't go up to the roof  to eat your lunch."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the best place to eat lunch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Three: Please--even if you are very  hot--do not go up to the roof to  sleep."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they think? They must think  we're crazy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think we're dumb niggers so we  need dumb rules--that's what they  think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the last one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men groan, in mock disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Four: There should be no going up  on the roof at night."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't they just say, "Stay off  the roof!"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they don't want us up there  *at all*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer crumples the list and throws it into the wood stove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer) That's *it*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means nothin' at all! And all  this time I been *wonderin'* about  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're *outrageous*, them rules!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who *live* here in this cider house,  Peaches? Who grind them apples, who  press that cider, who clean up the  mess, and who just plain *live*  here... just breathin' in the vinegar? (he pauses) Somebody who *don't* live here made  them rules. Them rules ain't for  *us*. *We* the ones who make up them  rules. We makin' our *own* rules,  every day. Ain't that right, Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera closes on Candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Candy sit and stare at the blank screen; they d look at each other. Candy grips the steering wheel of the parked car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't make me say it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not it--I just want to be  sure I understand you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy slumps forward with her forehead on the steering wh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I *helped* you not to think about  Wally. You were so upset--you couldn't  stand worrying about him, about his  being killed and not coming back-- but when you were with me, you could  stop worrying... well, for a while,  anyway. This is how I helped you,  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... that's enough. I *loved*  you, too--you know I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...did." Well, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) And now that Wally's coming back,  and because he'll certainly *need*  you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say that as though it's some  awful thing! (angrily) I never stopped loving Wally!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer lets that sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still sarcastic) At least there's no more waiting and  seeing. At least I got to see the  ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy covers her face in her hands and cries uncontrollab unstoppably. Homer's anger keeps him impervious to her te another "first" for him. He turns and looks at her with a almost clinical curiosity; then he goes back to staring a the blank screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has stopped but the grass is wet, the trees  glistening in the dawn light as Wally's car stops and Hom gets out. The car exits the frame in one direction; Homer walking, exits the frame in another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks toward the cider house, Homer sees Muddy and  Peaches and Hero waving to him from the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose has runned away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took off in the night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took off on the bicycle, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer starts jogging, then running toward the cider house Muddy comes down the ladder to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose Rose's bed is exposed. The curtains are flung open; bed is empty. Mr. Rose is still in his bed, in the fetal  position we have seen before. Mr. Rose's trancelike expre doesn't change as Homer and Muddy enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't nobody gonna find her, Homer-- she's long gone. (pause) I swear, I didn't try and stop her-- I just wanna touch her hand before  she go. That's all I wanna do, I  swear. (pause) Where'd she get that knife, Muddy?  That looked like *your* knife--what  I seen of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muddy is scared; he looks to Homer for advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that was your knife, Muddy, I  wanna thank you for givin' it to her-- no girl should be goin' *hitch-hikin'*  if she don't got a good knife with  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing the blood) Where'd she get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just plan misunderstand me--I  was tryin' to give her my knife, I  was just reachin' to touch her hand.  But I understand if she misunderstand  me--it's all my fault, ain't that  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer takes the blanket off him; Muddy gasps. Homer tries examine Mr. Rose's wound. Mr. Rose smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late for the doctor now,  Homer--ain't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer doesn't answer; he knows Mr. Rose is a goner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) She's *good* with that knife! She's  real fast. She's a lot better with  that knife than *you* is, Muddy! And  who do you suppose taught her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *You* taught her, I suppose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right! A girl's gotta know  how to defend herself, don't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He winces in pain at Homer's examination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) There's more than one laceration,  more than one cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's 'cause I sticked my *own*  knife in the wound--after she go, I  sticked my *own* knife in there. I  poked it all around, I just tryin'  to find the same place she got me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer finds Mr. Rose's knife. There's blood everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You listen to me: you tell them police  how this happen, you tell it *this*  way, you hear? My daughter, she runned  off--and I so sad about it that I  stabbed myself. I so unhappy that  she gone, I killed myself--that what  you say, you hear? That the true  story--ain't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Muddy exchange a glance. Mr. Rose, with his blo soaked hand, suddenly grabs Homer by the throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me hear you say that! I so unhappy  she runned away that I killed myself-- that what happen here, ain't that  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That what happen--you lost you only  daughter so's you killed yourself!  That's what we say, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. I know you understand  how I feel, Homer--you is breakin'  them rules, too. Ain't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rose dies. Muddy turns away. Homer closes Mr. Rose's  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muddy and Hero and Peaches are sitting close together on roof, like banished children. It is from their perspectiv that we see the police car and the ambulance--two men car the body out of the cider house, and a cop or two talking Homer and Olive, and Homer talking to them. We hear no  dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and the men load crates of apple jelly onto a truck The mood is solemn; they work with tired focus. Candy dri up. The men are evasive with her; they find a reason to w across the mart. Candy walks to Homer, stands next to him They say nothing for a moment, until Candy breaks the sil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think she'll be all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows how to take care of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy looks away; she can't think of what to say. She sho her hands into her pockets, finds a letter there, which s hands to Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This came for you a couple of days  ago. Olive asked me to bring it.  With everything happening, I guess  she forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks at the letter from St. Cloud's; he puts it  unopened in his pocket without a second thought. Candy ca let things end there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you don't think much of being  needed, or of me for that matter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for what I said about Wally  needing you. It was... unnecessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm the one who should be sorry.  You have every right to be angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You warned me. I didn't listen,  but you warned me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me you weren't any good at  being alone. (pause) You told Wally, too. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy can only stare straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relenting) He's going to be fine, Wally's going  to be fine. I know he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tear rolls down Candy's cheek, Homer wipes it away; the he stops touching her and looks off into the quiet orchar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickers lie in their beds, smoking. Homer is undressi He pulls the letter out of his pocket and sits down on hi bed. Homer opens the letter without enthusiasm and begins read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Homer, I am writing to tell you  about Wilbur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music is playing on the old phonograph as an exhausted La gives himself ether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna is getting the girls ready for bed. Music continues  Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larch has twisted himself on the narrow bed so that his f is unusually close to the windowsill, and when the ether  cone starts to fall off his face--and his slack hand trai down, off the side of the bed--the cone becomes caught ag the windowsill. He tries to turn his face away from the cone, but he pres his face into the sill--thus holding the ether-soaked con over his mouth and nose. His hands twitch, he's trying to wake up; the hand that holds the ether bottle lets the bo fall. The bottle shatters against the sill; the ether spr running red with blood from a cut on Dr. Larch's hand or  finger. Music continues Over. It's a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster is bringing in the wood as the music plays Over. B smells the spilled ether. He heads toward the dispensary, sniffing. Camera follows him into the dispensary. In the dispensary: Buster approaches Larch's ether-bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch? Dr. Larch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the armload of wood and runs for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela enters. She feels for Larch's pulse; Larch is dead Angela opens a window. She pull's Larch's body away from windowsill. Buster joins her on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can assure you that the overdose  was entirely accidental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer finishes reading the letter; he puts it down, gets and walks to a window. He stares into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us be happy for Dr. Larch. Dr.  Larch has found a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Dr. Larch! Good night,  Dr. Larch! Good night, Dr. Larch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer wipes a tear off his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck is packed for the long trip south; it passes by the packing house, which looks closed for the season. No else is about. Muddy is driving slowly, his arm out the o window. In the back, huddled among their belongings, are  Peaches and Hero (on one side) and Homer (on the other). pickers are trying to draw Homer into their conversation, while Homer is giving the apple farm a good-bye look. He made up his mind about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever see a palm tree, Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't never been outta Maine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you sick of pine trees, Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer just smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the pickers' truck drives past, Homer is on the side o the truck nearest the Worthington house and driveway; he  sees Olive and Candy and Ray helping Wally out of the car and into a wheelchair. A NURSE stands by. Wally is wearing what appears to be an oversized officer' coat or flight jacket, his face looking small in the over clothes. He can't move his legs at all, and his mouth is  drawn into a tight-lipped smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you somethin' about  Florida, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sunshine State!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so nice 'n' warm down there,  you can pick them grapefruits and  oranges *naked*, if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive is dissolved in tears. Candy is sobbing; she kisses Wally, without ceasing, while he haltingly touches her fa her hair. In the truck the smile is gone from Homer's face. He shak his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, guys... I'd like to go with  you. But I've got to move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... you could move on with  *us*, man! You could move on somewhere  *warm*!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, stayin' in Maine ain't movin'  on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This makes all the pickers laugh, but Homer just smiles a shakes his head. He watches the Worthington house disappe from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CONDUCTOR, taking tickets, comes to Homer, who is bette dressed than we've ever seen him; he is looking at his so reflection in the black window-glass of the night train w the conductor gets his attention. When the conductor move on, Homer takes Angela's letter out of his breast pocket; skips ahead to the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch often wondered how the  world was treating you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He talked a lot about you, hoping  you would be of use, whatever you  were up to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela and Buster and Mary Agnes and Edna carry Larch's  coffin; they set it down by the raw hole. The pile of fre dirt stands out against the new snow; the hole is black  against the new white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh, Lord, support us all the day  long..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the wheelbarrow with the gravestone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...until the shadows lengthen and  the evening comes, and the busy world  is hushed, and the fever of life is  over, and our work is done."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the faces of the girls praying for Larch (Mary Agn too) as Edna finishes her favorite prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Then, in Thy mercy grant us a safe  lodging, and a holy rest, and peace  at the last."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera closes on Homer, sleeping to the sound of the rock train. Angela's letter lies in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen! Amen! Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train stops, blowing snow. Homer steps off the train  carrying a suitcase and Dr. Larch's bag. The disapproving stationmaster is still disapproving. Music plays Over,  something triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer makes his way up the hill toward the orphanage. Mus Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna is breaking up fights; this time, instead of fightin over snowballs, the orphans are fighting over their pumpk Suddenly Homer tops the brow of the hill and they all see him. Buster is the first to catch sight of Homer; he runs toward him. Mary Agnes also sees Homer; she immediately t away and runs inside. Music FADES OUT Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Agnes crashes into the bathroom and stumbles up to t mirror; she starts to fix herself up with shaking hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has heard the news; they come on the run. The  children flock around Homer, hugging him. Homer takes Ang and Edna in his arms. Mary Agnes joins the group. Homer t in how changed, how attractive she is. They smile awkward at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer's suitcase is open on the bed; we see Homer's hands he begins to unpack. Smaller hands reach in and root thro the clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring something for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly continues his search. Homer thinks for a second; th reaches into his pocket and pulls out the piece of pale-g glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer hands the piece of glass to Curly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from the ocean. It's for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly is duly impressed; he walks away to examine his new treasure. Homer continues unpacking. He pulls his X ray o and puts it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer turns to see Buster, Mary Agnes, Angela, and Edna i the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made up a room for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you be more comfortable by  yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer smiles; he nods. Angela and Mary Agnes start to put Homer's things back in his bag. Edna picks up the X ray and looks at it with a s expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, do you know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. It's my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Actually, it's Fuzzy's. There's  nothing wrong with your heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuzzy's?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Larch wanted to keep you out of  the war, Homer--that's why he did  it. That's why he told you it was  yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer is stunned; he puts his hand to his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he worried about his own  heart. He said it would never stand  up to Homer Wells going off to war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer takes that in; he nods. Mary Agnes touches him  sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer looks at his fake diplomas; they are now framed and hanging on the office wall. Homer surveys the office, as for the first time; he sits down in the desk chair, as if slowly getting used to his new position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer reads to the boys from "David Copperfield". While h voice is strong--positive, optimistic, certainly reassuri to the boys--there is in the conclusion of the chapter  something that distracts him. He seems to hesitate; he mi a line or two, and perhaps he purposely skips one or two  others. (Possibly Homer's eyes wander ahead, to the title the next chapter: "I Make Another Beginning.")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Thus I began my new life, in a new  name, and with everything new about  me... I felt... like one in a dream...  The remembrance of that life is  fraught with so much... want of  hope... Whether it lasted for a year,  or more, or less, I do not know. I  only know that it was, and ceased to  be; and... there I leave it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer stops and looks at the boys' faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's tomorrow, Curly. Let's mot  give the story away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer puts out the lights and leaves the boys in the fami semi-darkness. Seconds, later, the closed door to the hal is flung open, flooding the room with light from the hall and Homer, dressed in his long white laboratory coat and  looking every inch the doctor, delivers his best imitatio of Larch's popular blessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, you Princes of Maine!  You Kings of New England!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Copperfield and Steerforth and Curly as the door to th hall is closed and semi-darkness prevails in the room aga Copperfield, smiling, shuts his eyes. After a second, the wide-eyed Steerforth shuts his eyes, too. Then Curly. The last to close his eyes is Buster.
